reviewText:
I've never played Knights of the Old Republic (and it's 2015) so my review will be based on my experience alone.

Personally, I don't think it's aged too well, graphically it looks like a PS2 game, the voice acting isn't great, and the default controls for a gamepad are missing some of the vital commands. (Support for gamepads are from a new update, but don't do the game full service)

However, the game seems to be rich in dialogue, characters, Star Wars lore, and filled with RPG elements and plenty of loot to make each step feel rewarding. It does a great job to make you feel like you are in a large Star Wars Universe filled with uncertanties and adventure. (controlling droids is actually pretty cool)

The combat system is... kind of dated. It's basically a real time action turn-based system where you select what attack you want to do, and your character will basically move for you and do the attack.  I kind of feel like this is where I was let down.  If there is ever a sequel, I'm hoping that it'll be more like an FPS or Third-Person with more user control.

Overall, I feel like it's a good, but a bit dated. If you are a fan of RPGs, want some Star Wars lore, and are okay playing with some PS2 era graphics / gameplay, than I'd definitely reccomend this for $5 or so.

reviewText:
Both a massive improvement and a massive disappointment over the first KotOR, this is, unfortunately, another one of Obsidian's rushed games. Through no fault of their own they were forced to release an unfinished game, leaving us with some plotlines that didn't go anywhere and quite a few bugs. Although Obsidian were denied the chance to fix their game through patches by Lucasarts, modders went to work on restoring a lot of cut content and fixing bugs. I waited for a lot of years and saw a couple projects dissolve, but eventually one came out and it's pretty great. I would recommend playing with The Sith Lords Restored Content Mod (TSLRCM) on a first playthrough, as without it you may be left with sour disappointment in some aspects of the game.

http://www.moddb.com/mods/the-sith-lords-restored-content-mod-tslrcm

On that page there's also the planet M4-78 which was cut from the game entirely. You can try it out but I personally did not like it very much. Even on a modern machine I ran into performance issues, and it felt awkward and long. I wouldn't recommend it for a first playthrough.

reviewText:
This game frustrates me so much. Unfortunately, like its predecessor, KOTOR II's Steam version is incredibly broken. Like with the original game, to even get past the opening logos I had to disable the game's movies. The resolution problems the previous game has are here too. I managed to play the prologue and the first chapter, but attempting to travel to the next planet via the galaxy map caused the game to crash every time I tried. Even if there was a way to fix this issue I'm not sure I would bother, as my desire to play this game has been completely sapped thanks to the host of issues it has. What makes this even more annoying is that from what I've played it actually looks to be a very good game. The gameplay is very similar to the original, but with more polish. The animations are more numerous and better done, the UI and menus are much simpler, and the voice acting is considerably better. However, it doesn't matter how good this game is because you won't be able to get far enough to enjoy it. The old Star Wars games available on Steam seem to be broken more than often than not, and I'm afraid Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic II is no exception.

Steam version: 2/10.

Don't buy the Steam version of this game. You would just be wasting your time.

reviewText:
Pros:
-Immersive star wars role playing experience
-Morality is more intricate than just light side/dark side this time
-Wide range of character customization
-Well developed companions
-Weapon customization (you can have whatever lightsaber color you want!)
-Large amount of content
-Relatively high replayability
-Nonlinear gameplay; player can choose to do the plots in whatever order they desire
-HK-47 and all his quotes

Cons:
-Cut content; Obsidian had to rush this game into retail, and had to cut a lot of content.  Thus, the plot has some noticeable gaps and seems choppy
-Mild bugginess, but nothing game breaking

Overall: First, it's worth mentioning that there is a Restored Content Mod that Obsidian took part in allowing.  This mod adds a lot of cut content, including an entire plot arc with HK-47, back into the game.  If you buy this, you should absolutely install that mod as well.

That said, Obsidian took up the reins and did the series justice.  It's unfortunate that they had to rush the game near the end, because the plot is fantastic and really deserved to have its day.  But the gameplay is still fun, immersive, and captivating, and the amount of customiztaion for your character has only increased from the first game.  It's a pleasure to play, and rarely does the game become tedious.  Instead it's just a fun ride from start to finish.

Bottom Line: Absolutely recommend

reviewText:
Okay, everyone gives this game a lot of ♥♥♥♥ for not being a worthy sequel of the first one. Everyone talks about how it was rushed, it's buggy, there's a lot of things unfinished, and honestly I can't really dispute those claims. BUT, this game, for me, is actually better than the first one.

The dialogue in this game surpasses KOTOR I's dialogue by leaps and bounds. Honestly, I have never, and probably never will, experience such incredible storytelling as Obsidian's writers managed to pull off. Your story of being the last Jedi, exiled from your rightful title after a horrible war, will drag you through the jungle moon of Dxun, the dry, evil sands of Korriban, and the gangster paradise of Nar Shaddaa, to name a few. The first character you meet, Kreia, shoud be forever considered one of the most interesting characters ever created in a video game. She is so mysterious and wise that you can't help but be influenced by her presence, and every dialogue tree with her makes you crave more after it's over.

I love the dynamism of light side and dark side in this game. Being the last Jedi, you can choose to walk the path of redemption, reclaiming your rightful title as Jedi once more, or doom the galaxy to eternal pain and suffering, becoming an incredibly powerful Sith Lord. All the possible choices you have in certain scenarios give you Light Side or Dark Side points, and building your character to become an unstoppable force, slaughtering everyone in sight, is hilariously entertaining.

I played the Xbox version previously before I bought it on the PC, and I can tell you, if you look up TSL Restoration Mod, the creators have done an AMAZING job bringing back all the things that Obsidian wasn't able to deliver on due to the rushed production. I think that many people think KOTOR II is inferior to I for this reason, but with the restoration, I don't think that there's any real argument that this game wouldn't have completely outshadowed KOTOR I in every way.

reviewText:
The better of the 2 Knights of the Old Republic game.
But only because this has a darker more adult storyline to it.
I know EA and Bioware say the canon version is to play a female character in this but dont beleive it for a second.

This game makes a ton more sense and has a ton more interaction when you play a male character (dont want to spoil it but a key figure in the storyline only joins your team if you play male character).

I have not tried the content patch that fills in all the missing content as Lucas Arts rushed Obsidian to release this originally, but even the content lite version was a excellent game.

I strongly recommend people purchase and play this game and dont take just my word for it, judge for yourself and play the male and female character through. You will see how expanded part of the story is as a male character and how empty it feels  when that content missing from the female storyline.

reviewText:
If you're a fan of any type of RPG - Star Wars or not - I guarantee that you'll love Knights of the Old Republic 2. It's execution is very simple yet very effective, something games tend to miss these days; being too complex for the sake of complexity.

The storyline (while a little cliche) is extremely well written and thought out, revealing itself slowly to the character as they make their own choices through the game. Characters like Atton Rand and especially Kreia have very deep and rich backstories that not only add to the fantastic story and atmosphere to the game, but will also change depending on what you do in the game. Depending on the choices you make, some characters will favor you while others will not. For example, if you decide to execute a criminal, one character might applaud you for such an action while another will disapprove. All these choices affect how much information you can gather from them during your playtime.

The combat is simple, and if you've played the original Knights of the Old Republic, you know exactly what to expect. This is not a bad thing, however. If you enjoy pause/point-and-click combat, then you have nothing to worry about.

Keep in mind, this game was released in 2005, so the graphics aren't going to be hyper-realistic and since the game was rushed during development constrictions, content WAS cut from the final release. That being said, there was a fan-made mod that actually restored all the lost content - You can find it with a simple google search: KOTOR 2 TSLRCM"

Had this game been given the time it deserved for development
date: it would have been WIDELY recognized as one of the best RPG's ever made. Nonetheless
recommended: Obsidian Entertainment did a fantastic job taking the reigns from Bioware
hoursPlayed: and formed a story that was ten-times more interesting and engaging than the first game
voteText:
introducing rich characters - both fearsome and loving - and bringing moral choices that sculpt your very adventure.

Do NOT miss this game - It's worth your time.

9/10"

reviewText:
A classic, now better than ever.
In a move rarely seen outside of moneygrabs, a company (Aspyr) has picked up a forgotten game after the collapse of the original owner company LucasArts. Aspyr hasn't added any content to the game, but they have ported it and updated it to run on modern computers. This includes Windows 10, Mac, and even Linux.

Plus Steam Workshop support has been added, though it should be used with caution. There's a crippling bug that causes the game to crash if you have more than 5 Workshop mods installed at once. This is easily circumvented, though, since there's still severeal KotOR2 mod sites still online with most of the same mods. I use Workshop for the Restored Content Mod and Skip Paragus. Everything else I install manually.

Graphically, there's no escaping that this game was originally designed with the PS2 and original Xbox in mind. The models are as chunky as they come, and some of the textures are downright blurry. Oddly, some textures are amazingly sharp and crisp, while others are not, and there's some fairly advanced shader effects scattered around that seem unlikely to be from the original version. It feels like Aspyr is slowly improving the textures and other graphics, but I cannot prove that.

As for the quality of the game itself, it's one of my favorites. I played the living tar out of this on my Xbox back in the day. It's a great story with plenty to explore and a combat system that allows some complex strategy. If you like to min/max stats, this is a great game for you. There's thousands of items all with unique stats and effects, as well as the ability to customize many items with upgrades. Specialize your characters to create synergy in combat.

GRIPES!
This is far from a perfect game.
In terms of Aspyr's changes, the game is much more playable than it was before, but there's still some problems. Workshop is only just working, as I've mentioned. Then there's an issue with the game minimizing every time there's a cutscene. It's only midly inconvenient, but it is worth mentioning. I like to think Aspyr's still working on these issues, though.

Then there's the issues with the game as it was and always will be. The start of the story is slow. Like crazy slow. It isn't bad the first time playing though, but after a few replays it gets very tedious since there's not a lot of choice you can make that early in the game. Fortunately, there's a mod to fix that.

reviewText:
I have severe bittersweet feelings for this game because it is incomplete.

The graphics, the custscenes, and NPCs are pretty dated but the narrative, the lore and the characters you encounter are rich and fleshed out well.

The characters give long soliloquies on their histories and motivations and towards the end they just kind of give up.

There is a restored patch mod but there are rumors entire planets were removed, as evidenced by one of the characters mentioning a future quest and never coming to fruition.

Also in the final dungeon you can see map markers of rooms with no doorways or tunnels connecting to them.

The devs rushed this game to completion and thus some of it's appendages were mercilessly cut out.

Then Bioware comitted an even greater sin by continuing the story in an MMO.

Consider this, if you play Mass Effect pretend they were all Star Wars characters and in that universe and you can get a sense of the Star Wars series of games we were robbed of.

10/10 will play again

reviewText: The KotOR series was probably one of my all-time favorites, I liked these way more than the movies and KotOR I was the game that truly got me into RPG games. KotOR II is just as good as the first and continues to move onward with the story and events after KotOR I. Age hasn't been too kind to it, the graphics aren't the best and it's buggy at best on newer OS, but that doesn't stop it from being a true legendary classic. And look at that, a decade later and it gets updated to fix most problems and allow for us to return to KotOR II a few more times. Just because it got this big update don't think it's bug free, there's still plenty of them. For me I get achievements in weird locations for no reason - I got the Dancing Queen achievement when I left Peragus and didn't get the Peragus achievement until I got a little further into Telos. Not to mention the money achievement I randomly got when I made a small barter - but that's okay. There's no real game breaking bugs or anything and it's stable. It's a very good game and is usually set at a low price. If you love Star Wars or RPGs on a whole this is a must have along with KotOR I. I recommend starting with KotOR I first then moving on to two as you'll probably get pretty confused. The combat system is similar to an MMO, usually I'm not a fan of this combat system in single-player games but it actually works pretty good. Granted it could be better, but for a 2005 game there's nothing wrong with it.

The first in a series of flawed diamonds by Obsidian.

It was a warm summer's day when Bioware was busy working on other projects that they had started and soon discovered that they couldn't fit KoToR 2 into their projects. So they walked over to Obsidian entertainment and knocked on the door and formed an agreement to allow Obsidian to develop KoTor 2 for them. However, Bioware was impatient so they only had a year of development time to work on it.

Obsidian sat down and immediatley got to work, as the studio only had around 10-15 people working in it at the time, all the time they had was invaluable. Lots of time was spent making assests that were never put into the final game, thus, time was spent. reviewText:
Allright, I have always wanted to make a review about this game, and now it's the time to do it.

This game came out in 2005. This year the Episode III also came out, so it was a big year of Star Wars to me.
As a kid the Star Wars galaxy was a big part of me, and still is.

Why is this relevant to this review?
Because Kotor 2 made me a real diehard fan of star wars. It's awesome story, it's voice acting, dark post-jedi war atmosphere that you can feel in the game world all the time and through dialog, the path you take: dark side and light side both have a lot of cool influence to the story, also the benefits of the allignments are pretty cool. And the prestige classes are awesome, imagine being a jedi weapon master, or a bad ♥♥♥ Darth Maul like Sith Assassin with a spinning double-blade.
The game is a big part of me, even with it's flaws like the bugs and plotholes, but after saying this there is a one thing........
As most of the guys in the Kotor 2 community may or may not know, there is a mod called Restored Content mod, or TSLRCM, that brings a huge amount of cut content back to the game, fixes the biggest plotholes, fixes a ton of bugs and makes the game even more awesome. Seriously, after playing with tslrcm for 4 years, I can't imagine to play without it. The game is really in its finished state with the mod. There you have it.
One of my all time favorites and close to my heart for sure.

reviewText:
[Note: this review assumes that the player will use the The Sith Lords Restored Content Mod (TSLRCM) from the game's workshop. This reviewer think that said mod is a necessary part of the game at this point and can't be separated from the vanilla game itself]
Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic II - The Sith Lords is a sequel to the original roleplaying game by BioWare by Obsidian Entertainment. Set once again centuries before the Star Wars' movies timeline, The Sith Lords' story picks up immediately where the story of the first game ended: the galactic Republic is now in disarray due to the Jedi civil war and Sith forces still run rampart through its planets, with the Jedi order in ruin and no Force practicioneers in sight. You take the role of a Jedi who has been exiled from his/her order before the civil war and your objective is to survive the dark forces coming after you and discover the true reasons behind your punishment and the origin of your peculiar connection to the Force.
As far the gameplay goes, the Sith Lords manages to be a better roleplaying game than its predecessor. Several gameplay elements have been overhauled or change to support different styles of play and to truly allow you to build a character following your tastes AND be able to overcome the game's challenges. While in the first Knights of the Old Republic the balance favored pure melee Jedi characters, now other specializations and characters have a chance too: enemies are less prone to resist Force powers, making them viable for pure damage or CC, and both melee weapons and blasters can now benefit from unique upgrades that really give lightsabers a run for their money. It's worth mentioning however that the Sith Lords' endgame somehow favors caster characters: by that point in the game the Force points (your mana, if you will) regen rateo has become gargantuan, allowing you to spam damaging spells or incapacitating effects ad nauseam (something that becomes really useful, since the last portion of the game are a series of straight fights against crowds of opponents).
The Sith Lords' main new gameplay gimmick is the influence system. The companions you travel with will react to your actions and choices, approving them or else following their own moral compass and objectives: therefore, your influence with them will increase or decrease accordingly. Having an high influence with a character means unlocking new conversation options and even the possibility to turn him/her into a Jedi. The main downside of the influence system is however that the parameter is increased mainly during world events, so you'll manage to get a good influence with the characters you'll use most only. Another gimmick the game likes to throw at you is the sudden playable characters changes: at many points during the game you will be forced to put aside your main character to play in the shoes of one or more companions. While these sequences are interesting in their own right and have their place in the main story, they can easily becomes frustrating if you are forced to play a character you are not familiar with or whom you neglected beforehead.
Knights of the Old Republic II is also infamous for the somehow shifting quality of its levels. There are some levels that are universally loathed by the playerbase, with the two main examples being Peragus (which is quite long for being your first proper level after the tutorial prologue, with the story going on at a snail's pace) and Nar Shaddaa (which is another planet that takes far too long as far as the main quest goes, requires a lot of backtracking and has a brutal endgame). Also, the final area of the game, Malachor V, hasn't many fans around due to having been hit the worst by the rushed development cycle and consisting in a series of straight fights against several opponents with little to none interaction or exploration involved.
Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic II - The Sith Lords remains a very divisive game in pretty much ever aspect, even the story and the setting. Some people like the deconstruction the writers wanted to pull off on the Star Wars canon as a whole and the main morality system of the series, while others find it pretentious and too much shoehorned. Some people see the game as an incomplete, rushed mess, while others can somehow get past the blatantly missing part and enjoy what they got their hands on. Personally, while the Sith Lords could had been a far stronger sequel and a Star Wars RPG in its own right, I found myself enjoying it more often than not due to the high level of the writing, the refined and more custom gameplay and its central interesting themes

reviewText:
At this point, if you are looking at this page you doubtlessly know about KotOR 2's reputation for being buggy and incomplete. Just to make sure you know: this wasn't the studio's fault - LucasArts gave them less than half the time they actually needed to finish the game. Still, a review isn't about what something could have been but rather, what something is.

If you liked KotOR 1, KotOR 2 is more of that but refined, enhanced, and... admittedly, yes, buggier. However, the bugs (in general) are rarely crippling and the more serious ones tend to be both not universally experienced, and tend to only occur in side missions (like swoop racing). As for gameplay, combat is streamlined while still providing plenty of options for variety what with blasters, lightsabers, Force powers, and special attacks. Feats, equipment and their myriad upgrades, and to a lesser degree skills allow for crazy amounts of customization while remaining simple enough to easily understand.

The story is really where KotOR 2 shines through, though. As mentioned before, the game was a rushed job and much had to get cut at the last moment, however aside from the final stretch most missing plot threads are in the minor side quests and are only missing the very end that some may not even notice. Dialogue is natural and is one of the few examples where dialogue trees actually work well. Very little exposition (if any at all) is given straight through endless monologues, but is woven in from bits and pieces grasped from various characters (including the main - no amnesiacs here) including some who outright lie (and well, might I add)! Every playable character is well characterized with great personalities and motivations that are believeable enough not to make us question why they hate everyone else on the ship stick to the main character regardless (except maybe Visas...)
This game is also much darker than it's predecessor. It's enough that whether you liked or were simply lukewarm towards the original Star Wars trilogy of movies while the new trilogy left you cold, you are practically guaranteed to appreciate this game. On the other hand, if you really liked all of the Star Wars movies you may find the departure from the standard too much for your tastes. Honestly, despite the lightsabers and Jedi, there are points when KotOR 2 almost doesn't even feel like Star Wars (which I actually liked, to be honest).

One last thing that is worth mentioning - while a significant portion of the game was unfinished at the time of its release, a group of fans have been digging up the not-quite-removed game files, finishing them up, and reconnecting them to the game. It is very well done (particularly for a group of fans digging through broken scraps), adds much to the game, and helps fill in most of the holes in the story. Just search for The Sith Lords Restored Content Mod.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
The Sequel to the Bioware masterpiece, Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic II - The Sith Lords, is another incredible gaming experience and an important addition to the Star Wars universe. This game has a much darker undertone than its predecessor and although the plot arc isn't quite as rewarding as the first game, it still manages to stay faithful to it with an interesting plot twist. The gameplay is enhanced from the original with more feats, powers, weapons, customization options, and levels available, as well as new Jedi and sith prestige classes. The squad you recruit changes depending on your gender, and your alignment with the force, and some can be trained to use the force and become Jedi. Squad members remain interesting characters and now change based on the player's interactions with them. Several characters from the first game return (though not all are playable characters) and the Ebon Hawk is still your personal starship. Your journey takes you to a handful of worlds in the Star Wars Universe, some are new and some you may remember visiting or hearing about from the first game.
For a more enjoyable and complete experience I would recommend all players download the TSL: RCM from the workshop or internet. The Sith Lords Restored Content Modification add in many things that the original game lacked due to time constraints in development. A community project which took many years to perfect, this mod adds a whole slew of new content to the game which big or small, makes the overall experience twice as enjoyable. For those who have only played the Xbox version of the game, or did not previously have the mod installed, you will find that this mod makes it a whole new experience.

The recent update that adds achievements and workshop support is the best thing to happen to this game in the last decade. Now that everyone can add mods to this game AND earn some achievements, this game has new life breathed into it. I give it a 9/10.

I am about halfway through the game right now, playing through for the first time and wow wow wow. I am a huge fan of the first game, and this takes it to a whole new level. Basically the same software as the first game, same graphics and menus and all, but the gameplay has been expanded so much, and there is so much more you can do and NEED to pay attention to.

-The updated crafting system, which involves salvaging items and creating weapons, armor, and modifications for both, is really addicting and much more deep than KotOR 1.

- The dialogue options and personal connections you can achieve with the characters is amazing, including the Lore, the relationships possible, the twists (most of which I have yet to experience I'm sure) are, again, very deep and enjoyable to explore.

- The locations and planets you visit are large and worth of the Obsidian/Bioware partnership. These dev's are well known for the deep content they are able to produce, and the large worlds they can create.

George Lucas would ♥♥♥♥ his pants if he played this game. There are things about Star Wars in this that he probably doesn't even know. If you like Star Wars and RPG's, MUST BUY

reviewText:
I'm going to be frank and say that this is probably one of the best-written video games I've ever played.  With a bevy of plot-twists and an engaging system of character building in d20 format, Knights of the Old Republic 2 grabbed my attention and never dropped it.

Obsidian's trademark writing style is in full tilt here as they show off their amazing ability to elaborate on characters such that you know precisely who you're talking to in-depth beyond surface layers that most companies would present, and unlike the way KOTOR 1 was handled by Bioware, you're not a moustache-twirling cartoonish loony if you go for the Dark Side choices.

The game is deeply philosophical and looks into what it really means to be a Force Sensitive person; it provides an interesting perspective into the nature of the Force that in my opinion isn't really seen very much elsewhere via both the insight and backstory of one of your companions and your own personal journey through the story.

The biggest cons that I would give to it are that it's unpolished.  I'm not sure if Obsidian built themselves up over an indian burial ground or what happened but it seems like these guys just -cannot- catch a break when it comes to actually getting enough time to finish their product before it gets rushed to the market.  There's a lot of amazing content that's restored by the appropriately named Sith Lords Restoration Project and its sister issues, including scraps of what was left of an -entire droid planet- and several storylines that were kiboshed and remained partially in or were stripped completely from the remainder of the game.  This adds several hours of playtime and is really worth it in the long run if you want the full experience even if you can easily tell for the most part what's been spliced back in by a modding team (the scenes in many cases weren't complete).

Personally, uh, if you're going to go for the complete experience, though, I'd recommend you skip the Droid Planet. Last I checked that fan-project was unstable and buggy, not to mention really long-slogging and full of lag.  Might be worth it for a completionist, but there just wasn't enough data left to make it seem worthwhile.  Correct me if I'm wrong, folks.

Anyway, finishing up, get this game.  It's worth it just to sit back and listen to some of the conversations.  The gameplay's just a plus.

reviewText:
I awoke in an unknown place in space, missing most of my clothes and armed with nothing but what swings between my legs. After a quick,  failed attempt to find pants I instead found a creepy old woman who insists she knows me. My God, what did I do last night? I immediately made a vow that would be the last time I drink at a cantina on an empty stomach. In my heart, though, my fingers were crossed.

After wandering around an semi-abandoned mining station with this woman and a guy I had to restrain myself not to punch, we fled on a ship while running from arguably the ashiest man I had ever seen in my life. No amount of lotion in this galaxy could undo years of poor skin treatment. The ashy man said he knew the old woman, and it began to click...did I meet him last night too? I didn't...no...I wouldn't entertain the thought of touching such such dry, dry skin.

If only all RPGs began like this and ended with me fighting with lightsabers. A must play for any Star Wars fan, as it teaches you the dangers of not moisturising your skin properly can lead to dire consequences.

reviewText:
A classic, now better than ever.
In a move rarely seen outside of moneygrabs, a company (Aspyr) has picked up a forgotten game after the collapse of the original owner company LucasArts. Aspyr hasn't added any content to the game, but they have ported it and updated it to run on modern computers. This includes Windows 10, Mac, and even Linux.

Plus Steam Workshop support has been added, though it should be used with caution. There's a crippling bug that causes the game to crash if you have more than 5 Workshop mods installed at once. This is easily circumvented, though, since there's still severeal KotOR2 mod sites still online with most of the same mods. I use Workshop for the Restored Content Mod and Skip Paragus. Everything else I install manually.

Graphically, there's no escaping that this game was originally designed with the PS2 and original Xbox in mind. The models are as chunky as they come, and some of the textures are downright blurry. Oddly, some textures are amazingly sharp and crisp, while others are not, and there's some fairly advanced shader effects scattered around that seem unlikely to be from the original version. It feels like Aspyr is slowly improving the textures and other graphics, but I cannot prove that.

As for the quality of the game itself, it's one of my favorites. I played the living tar out of this on my Xbox back in the day. It's a great story with plenty to explore and a combat system that allows some complex strategy. If you like to min/max stats, this is a great game for you. There's thousands of items all with unique stats and effects, as well as the ability to customize many items with upgrades. Specialize your characters to create synergy in combat.

GRIPES!
This is far from a perfect game.
In terms of Aspyr's changes, the game is much more playable than it was before, but there's still some problems. Workshop is only just working, as I've mentioned. Then there's an issue with the game minimizing every time there's a cutscene. It's only midly inconvenient, but it is worth mentioning. I like to think Aspyr's still working on these issues, though.

Then there's the issues with the game as it was and always will be. The start of the story is slow. Like crazy slow. It isn't bad the first time playing though, but after a few replays it gets very tedious since there's not a lot of choice you can make that early in the game. Fortunately, there's a mod to fix that.

reviewText:
At this point, if you are looking at this page you doubtlessly know about KotOR 2's reputation for being buggy and incomplete. Just to make sure you know: this wasn't the studio's fault - LucasArts gave them less than half the time they actually needed to finish the game. Still, a review isn't about what something could have been but rather, what something is.

If you liked KotOR 1, KotOR 2 is more of that but refined, enhanced, and... admittedly, yes, buggier. However, the bugs (in general) are rarely crippling and the more serious ones tend to be both not universally experienced, and tend to only occur in side missions (like swoop racing). As for gameplay, combat is streamlined while still providing plenty of options for variety what with blasters, lightsabers, Force powers, and special attacks. Feats, equipment and their myriad upgrades, and to a lesser degree skills allow for crazy amounts of customization while remaining simple enough to easily understand.

The story is really where KotOR 2 shines through, though. As mentioned before, the game was a rushed job and much had to get cut at the last moment, however aside from the final stretch most missing plot threads are in the minor side quests and are only missing the very end that some may not even notice. Dialogue is natural and is one of the few examples where dialogue trees actually work well. Very little exposition (if any at all) is given straight through endless monologues, but is woven in from bits and pieces grasped from various characters (including the main - no amnesiacs here) including some who outright lie (and well, might I add)! Every playable character is well characterized with great personalities and motivations that are believeable enough not to make us question why they hate everyone else on the ship stick to the main character regardless (except maybe Visas...)
This game is also much darker than it's predecessor. It's enough that whether you liked or were simply lukewarm towards the original Star Wars trilogy of movies while the new trilogy left you cold, you are practically guaranteed to appreciate this game. On the other hand, if you really liked all of the Star Wars movies you may find the departure from the standard too much for your tastes. Honestly, despite the lightsabers and Jedi, there are points when KotOR 2 almost doesn't even feel like Star Wars (which I actually liked, to be honest).

One last thing that is worth mentioning - while a significant portion of the game was unfinished at the time of its release, a group of fans have been digging up the not-quite-removed game files, finishing them up, and reconnecting them to the game. It is very well done (particularly for a group of fans digging through broken scraps), adds much to the game, and helps fill in most of the holes in the story. Just search for The Sith Lords Restored Content Mod.

reviewText:
In light of the recent patches to the game, I'm going to have to stick with my very ambitious but flawed gem answer. It's Obsidian doing what they do best, setting lofty goals for their projects and just barely missing the mark because they bit off more than they could chew.

The Peragus mining facility goes on for far too long. It could have been cut in half or just cut entirely with you starting off on Telos. The fact Peragus/Telos is so long makes replaying the game unappealing solely because of how much time you have to sink into the game before you're finally allowed to explore the other planets. Many story arcs and companions are woefully underdone and stand in stark contrast to the ones that are well written and very fleshed out. Another minute complaint is that Handmaiden and Disciple are not very well balanced against themselves, they shouldn't have had identical stats and feats.

All that aside, I like the more somber tone this game has over it's predcessor. The few story arcs they did finish are interesting, the few companions they did flesh out are really well done. The skills are balanced against themselves, no one of them is so bad it should never be taken by the PC. The crafting was very well implemented. The amount of customization allowed for with your companions and the flexibility of the Exile leaves you for a lot of room to mix and match, something I really enjoy in games like this.

Warts and all, I still think the positives of this outweigh the negatives. Look into the Restored Content fan patch, it adds a lot of interesting things and implements some of the content that had to be left on the cutting floor due to time and budget retraints.

reviewText:
This is a deeply brilliant game, but it's flaws are real and present.

the original release was brutally cut for financial reasons and released early, full of bugs and plot holes. it's derivative of the original and suffers a muddier plot, disjointed and abandoned story threads and muddled antagonists that don't drive the narrative.

But there was clearly something here, and it was based on one of the best RPGs to date. Every game system is a refinement and extension of the first game; but more elegantly implemented and more polished.  The events and world of this story are natural outgrowths of the back-story or events of the first game;  but where the first game barely sketched the universe with stock characters, this game renders the fine details of the darkest days of the old republic with complex and compelling characters.

This is a game that tells the aftermath of the hero's journey. Depicted is a galaxy limping off and winding down after the great blows struck by the Mandalorian wars (in the back-story to the first game) and the Jedi civil war (the last half of which are the events of the first game).

The more complicated plot hides multiple interlocking stories, telling many tragedies. the characters are all richly developed, but there are no simple heroes or outright villains. the heroes are all tragic, with deep character flaws that drive them more then the events.  There are no clear villains because even the villains are tragedies in their own right, deftly interwoven with the larger narrative, and each a demonstration of their failures and a warning of the danger of their paths.

Years of work by the community have restored the cut content and revealed the ambitious pattern of story threads lost to budget and time. Community fixes have corrected bugs and fixed issues, even to the point of hex editing and reverse engineering. Even the developers have gotten into the act, releasing a patch 10 years after publication (and subsequent commercial failure) adding support for high resolution wide screen monitors, steam achievements, and workshop mods.

Now we have a game that approaches realization of the ambition of the developers, and delivers on that narrative with competence, provided you're willing to take the time and spend the effort to breath with it. Taken on it's own, it's fractious and oppressive world is a cautionary tale of hubris, but when combined with the original, it's a dark counterbalance to that bright tale, putting both into sharp relief. This truly is the “Empire” to the original KotOR's “New Hope”.

This is a deeply flawed game, but there is a genius beneath it's surface.

reviewText:
In light of the recent patches to the game, I'm going to have to stick with my very ambitious but flawed gem answer. It's Obsidian doing what they do best, setting lofty goals for their projects and just barely missing the mark because they bit off more than they could chew.

The Peragus mining facility goes on for far too long. It could have been cut in half or just cut entirely with you starting off on Telos. The fact Peragus/Telos is so long makes replaying the game unappealing solely because of how much time you have to sink into the game before you're finally allowed to explore the other planets. Many story arcs and companions are woefully underdone and stand in stark contrast to the ones that are well written and very fleshed out. Another minute complaint is that Handmaiden and Disciple are not very well balanced against themselves, they shouldn't have had identical stats and feats.

All that aside, I like the more somber tone this game has over it's predcessor. The few story arcs they did finish are interesting, the few companions they did flesh out are really well done. The skills are balanced against themselves, no one of them is so bad it should never be taken by the PC. The crafting was very well implemented. The amount of customization allowed for with your companions and the flexibility of the Exile leaves you for a lot of room to mix and match, something I really enjoy in games like this.

Warts and all, I still think the positives of this outweigh the negatives. Look into the Restored Content fan patch, it adds a lot of interesting things and implements some of the content that had to be left on the cutting floor due to time and budget retraints.

reviewText:
I highly recommend this game, it has what is in my opinion the best story out of any game I've ever played.

If you have never played this and decide to get it, keep these things in mind:

The game is super old, and not everything it does has held up over the years.

The game was released unfinished and unpolished, so it is *highly* suggested that before you even start the game for the first time you download the Restored Content mod.

Due to the age of the game, don't expect the most amazing graphics ever.

This is the type of game that will expect you to occasionally solve fairly challenging puzzles and will *not* hold your hand through some of the more challenging areas. As thus, don't be afraid to reference guides if you get stuck

There are occasionally game breaking bugs, but those are super rare and generally very easy to fix.

With that, I hope you enjoy the game.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you're a fan of The Old Republic MMO, this should probably be a game you should consider, especially if you're a lore junkie like me. The Knights of the Old Republic games are not only great RPG games, but they're also rich in Star Wars Lore. I played this game back when it first came out and since then it's hard to get the original CDs to install and run correctly on modern systems. Thankfully Steam offers this version of KOTOR and KOTOR 2 which are compatible for Modern Systems.

Knights of the Old Republic II (or KOTOR2) is set roughly five years after the events of the first KOTOR and feautres a new protaganist: The Jedi Exile. The Galaxy is picking up the pieces from the Jedi Civil War. Most of the Galaxy's surviving Jedi have either been killed or gone deep into hiding while a trio of Sith Lords, Darth Sion, Darth Nihilus, and a third unknown Sith Lord hunt down the Jedi with the intent of wiping them all out and finishing them off. Along the way, the Exile picks up allies such as the scoundrel and smuggler, Atton Rand, the mysterious blind woman Kreia, and Bao Dur the Iridonian technician. Some familiar faces come along for the ride as well such as T3-M4 and the fan favorite HK-47. Plus if you've played the original Knights of the Old Republic, you'll recognize the voice coming through the speakers of Mandalore's mask.

It's the first game I can think of where your character's gender and alignment detemines which allies you get. Males get the Handmaiden, an Echani woman who serves the Jedi yet isn't one due to an oath she and her sisters swore. Females get the Disciple, a researcher and historian looking into the Jedi and tries to determine their fate. Light Siders get Mira, a Bounty Huntress with a grenade/dart launcher on her wrist while Dark Siders get a deranged Wookiee with a bad attitude.

In terms of gameplay, KOTOR 2 takes the gameplay features of the original KOTOR and improves on it. Combat is virtually unchanged but other mechanics are improved such as the ability to equip two sets of weapons and swap between them as the need arises without having to go into the inventory screen to swap out blasters for a lightsaber. You also gain the ability to craft items such as blasters, simple armor sets, bladed weapons, and other items with a relatively simple crafting menu at workbenches and first aid stations. How you interact with your allies and other people determines how they react to you. Certain characters favor evil actions and become less willing to speak with you if you perform good actions. There are other characters who behave the opposite way and then there are characters like T3-M4 who is completely neutral and doesn't react either way.

Prior to the Great Canon Purge" after Disney acquired Lucasfilm and all of its associated properties
date: the Jedi Exile was recognized as a female named Meetra Surik who stayed true to the Light Side of the Force and the Jedi. However
recommended: you don't have to adhere to Canon and can play this game however you want."

reviewText:
Pros:
-Immersive star wars role playing experience
-Morality is more intricate than just light side/dark side this time
-Wide range of character customization
-Well developed companions
-Weapon customization (you can have whatever lightsaber color you want!)
-Large amount of content
-Relatively high replayability
-Nonlinear gameplay; player can choose to do the plots in whatever order they desire
-HK-47 and all his quotes

Cons:
-Cut content; Obsidian had to rush this game into retail, and had to cut a lot of content.  Thus, the plot has some noticeable gaps and seems choppy
-Mild bugginess, but nothing game breaking

Overall: First, it's worth mentioning that there is a Restored Content Mod that Obsidian took part in allowing.  This mod adds a lot of cut content, including an entire plot arc with HK-47, back into the game.  If you buy this, you should absolutely install that mod as well.

That said, Obsidian took up the reins and did the series justice.  It's unfortunate that they had to rush the game near the end, because the plot is fantastic and really deserved to have its day.  But the gameplay is still fun, immersive, and captivating, and the amount of customiztaion for your character has only increased from the first game.  It's a pleasure to play, and rarely does the game become tedious.  Instead it's just a fun ride from start to finish.

Bottom Line: Absolutely recommend

reviewText:
If you're a fan of any type of RPG - Star Wars or not - I guarantee that you'll love Knights of the Old Republic 2. It's execution is very simple yet very effective, something games tend to miss these days; being too complex for the sake of complexity.

The storyline (while a little cliche) is extremely well written and thought out, revealing itself slowly to the character as they make their own choices through the game. Characters like Atton Rand and especially Kreia have very deep and rich backstories that not only add to the fantastic story and atmosphere to the game, but will also change depending on what you do in the game. Depending on the choices you make, some characters will favor you while others will not. For example, if you decide to execute a criminal, one character might applaud you for such an action while another will disapprove. All these choices affect how much information you can gather from them during your playtime.

The combat is simple, and if you've played the original Knights of the Old Republic, you know exactly what to expect. This is not a bad thing, however. If you enjoy pause/point-and-click combat, then you have nothing to worry about.

Keep in mind, this game was released in 2005, so the graphics aren't going to be hyper-realistic and since the game was rushed during development constrictions, content WAS cut from the final release. That being said, there was a fan-made mod that actually restored all the lost content - You can find it with a simple google search: KOTOR 2 TSLRCM"

Had this game been given the time it deserved for development
date: it would have been WIDELY recognized as one of the best RPG's ever made. Nonetheless
recommended: Obsidian Entertainment did a fantastic job taking the reigns from Bioware
hoursPlayed: and formed a story that was ten-times more interesting and engaging than the first game
voteText:
introducing rich characters - both fearsome and loving - and bringing moral choices that sculpt your very adventure.

Do NOT miss this game - It's worth your time.

9/10"

reviewText:
A great sequel to the original. Very smooth and balanced gameplay. Recommend getting the Restored Content Mod.

Pros
-Okay story (Doesn't compare to the original)
-Engaging planets

-You can make nearly all of your party jedi

Cons
-Incomplete (Lots of bugs, unfinished missions)
-Tutorial planet very linear and boring (Peragus Skip Mod does wonders)
-Dark Side runs not as fun as the first game

Overall 6/10, recommended at reduced price; play the original first.

reviewText: In terms of gameplay it makes many improvements on the game mechanics of the first KotOR but suffers from occasional game-breaking bugs.  The real reason you want to play this game is because it has the best-written narrative of any SW game and is one of the best D&D-style RPGs ever made.  There is some great character writing and an interesting deconstruction of the Star Wars universe.   The inconclusive ending is probably the most controversial aspect of the game but with TSLRCMod (which you should install for your first playthrough) it raps things up a little better.  If you're looking for a lighthearted adventure and the feel of the first game this may not be for you.

reviewText: This game... I have a lot of great memories of this game right here. I've spent hundreds of hours and countless playthroughs on this title because of how well crafted the characters and the story are. The game picks up five years after the prequel, however the game doesn't require any previous knowledge of it's precursor to play, though it does have more than a few nods. Modding is now officially supported via the workshop, and several fixes to the games bugs and a few missing plot devices have been filled in, increasing the games already amazing plot. If you enjoy RPGs and/or are a Star Wars fan, then this game will definetly appeal to you.

reviewText:
I have heard a lot of people say that this one does not even compare to the original... I strongly disagree. So far, this one is BETTER than the original. In the following ways especially:
- Allows you to CREATE items and not simply and only upgrade. Although you can do that to and the variety of upgrades are much larger too.
- Walking around is much easier, A and D actually turn your character now.
- The graphics are MUCH better should you adjust your settings accordingly.
- Swoop racing is much more fun.
- Combat mechanics have drastically improved.
- Looting things is a lot nicer. It will tell you if something is empty on your screen so that you know you have been there already.
- There are three options for hacking/slicing things. You can either slice, bash, or you can use an explosive which really simplifies things.
- There are more but I do not want to take the time to list them.

I have been very impressed with this game so far and look forward to progressing through it.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
WHat can I possibly say about KOTOR that hasn't been said yet?
This game and KOTOR 1 are, to me, possibly the best games in the SW-franchise.
I love the setting, thousands of years before the events in the movies. They did well with the vibe and stuff.

However, please keep in mind that these games are rather old. They did work well on Steam (while the version I bought at a store and installed from a DVD required a ton of fiddling until they actually worked). They are not looking great anymore, but if you are into the story, check this out... it's such a fun story with a big twist/surprise (which of course, by now, everyone knows about).

It's not quite as much fun when you play through it again, even though you can go for a different class, but the whole storyline, visiting those iconic places, unravelling the secrets is a ton of fun.
one of the best RPGs ever for me, and if you don't mind playing very outdated (graphically) games, and you like SW and/or RPGs, make sure to get this!

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Obsidian no surprises here has taken the Knights of the Old Republic franchise and actually improved it gameplay wise by implementing new features like a more advanced crafting system, the lightsaber forms and a wider range of abilities in general. I was particularly overjoyed by the lightsaber forms as I felt Obsidian had paid close attention to the Star Wars lore and each form brought something new to the table and promoted a more strategic approach to fights.

Story wise, I felt Obsidian made an impressive story but it did feel a little too cryptic and convoluted at times and I have to admit that the first game set the bar very high with the amazing twist which this game lacked. However, the characters were astounding and I loved the Handmaiden's backstory in particular and I could tell that Obsidian had invested a lot of thought and time to make these characters relatable and likeable.

I felt that this game was less bug ridden than it's predecessor and it ran smoother altogether which is always nice even though it wasn't free of bugs entirely as at times some cutscenes skipped for whatever reason. Once again, the choices you make in the game heavily influence what kind of character you become and the interactions you have with your crew and Obsidian proves that KOTOR is one of the best titles when it comes to decision making.

Another triumph by Obsidian here and a more than worthy sequel and I expect more greatness from them in the future.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
So I've owned KOTOR 2 for many years now. I got it for Christmas the year it came out, same as the original. Since then, I've owned 2 more copies of the game, one on the original xBox, and then this version on Steam.

First off, this game is amazing. Comparing it to the original, it keeps a lot of the good, and makes most of it better. Don't come into this game expecting an amazing story based on your character, however, because rather than that, it gives you an amazing (and in my opinion, better) story based on how your character's actions affect your companions and the galaxy as a whole.

While this game's combat and mechanics are basically the same as the original KOTOR, several mechanics are much deeper than before. Upgrading is greatly expanded, giving many options for creating your ultimate weapons. Creating and Breaking Down items has been added, forcing you to decide on what to sell and what to break down into components, in order to create another weapon or item. And since this game focuses on companions, an influence mechanic has been implemented into your interactions with them. Now, what you say and do can change how your companions look at you and change their light and dark side orientation.

Now, for the bad. This game is packed full of amazing content, but due to some issues, the game is left… unfinished. The final few areas are lacking. The developers were rushed for the end of the game, and it feels lacking. Luckily, there is a fix for this. The Restored Content Mod is available here on Steam, and helps to fill in the gaps and slightly clear up the problems the developers left behind.

As for the quality of this version, it is superior to the other two I owned. The others were riddled with bugs, and frequently crashed. This version hasn't crashed once in the hundred hours or so that I've played it. On top of that, it is extremely easy to get mods for the game, some of which are very important (such as the Restored Content Mod), for creating a better experience for your game.

reviewText:
I just finished playing the game and it took my 47 hours to do just about everything the game had to offer. I played with the mod TSLRCM.

Here are my thoughts on this game:
All in all I would rate this as one of the greatest Action Roleplaying Games on PC (Fallout, Baldurs Gate 2, Mass Effect, etc.) but I have to admit this left me with somewhat mixed feelings.

Game was developed really fast (less than one year!?) and well - it shows. You cannot rush a masterpiece.

Let´s start with the bad stuff (Cons)
* All in all game feels so unfinished and there´s so many places and parts in the game where you have to wonder I bet this would have been great with one more year of time for developers"
* There are some annoying bugs. E.g. after combat ends your characted gets stuck and even though there are tips that say you should turn off/on the V-sync they really don´t help in all cases (e.g. in my case). You can live with this bug as it is totally random and doesn´t happen all the time and when it does you just have to F4+F5 (quick save + quick load) after the battles.
* Difficulty is so unbalanced and this most likely is due to lack of play testing. Some parts are almost impossible and some parts (most of the game) perhaps too easy. The difficult parts are the ones where you have to play without your main character and if you haven´t micromanaged and optimized the NPCs in your party really carefully. Also some skills are overbowered and some are underbowered. Same goes for items and weapons and well...just about everything
* Ending...let´s just say the last place you go in your adventure takes you gets grindy and repetative. Not a worthy ending for otherwise solid story
* Then there are small things which are kinda "90s" like the inventory management

But even with those all flaws I highly recommend this game. Story is great
date: the NPCs in your party are well written and there´s lots of humour and good dialogue in the game. I would rate this as one of the best Star Wars saga games and to good thing is that this feels so fresh because this takes place soooo long before the Movies that you don´t know the story in advance."

reviewText:
'Knights of the Old Republic' is my favourite 'Star Wars' game to date in part due to its epic scope. Plus, since it came out after 'Attack of the Clones', 'KOTOR' pretty much turned into the prequel that many of us wished we got instead. I remember playing the game for 48 hours straight this one time instead of studying for my finals. (It was this 48-hour gaming marathon that made me swear off epic gaming sessions for good.) That was more than a decade ago, and those good times still mean a lot to me.

Despite being a big fan of 'KOTOR', I never played 'KOTOR II: The Sith Lords'. I strongly believed it then that Bioware should have made the sequel, and I refused to pay full price for a game that was buggy at launch, especially when they should have learned from 'KOTOR''s buggy launch that got fans upset. Learning that some game content were also cut in order for the developers to meet the release date made me even less interested in giving 'KOTOR II' a try.

Thanks to Aspyr and the hardworking modding community, 'KOTOR II' was patched up and had its cut content restored recently. Given that, I decided to finally give 'KOTOR II' a try. The game that I played was modded with the Restored Content Modification v.1.8.4. So how did 'KOTOR II' measure up over a decade later?

What I enjoyed most about 'KOTOR II' is that some in-game and Force alignment decisions are neither clearly Light nor clearly Dark, resulting in more challenging decision making and requiring more self relfection. Furthermore, your character has the ability to influence other party members, leading to different ways characters can develop. Plus, the conversations that you can have with your party members, such as Kreia, Visas and Brianna, are some of the best bits of writing in 'Star Wars' lore I have seen to date.

Unfortunately, the patched and modded version of 'KOTOR II' that I played was still very buggy. The game camera occasionally stuttered or spun around non-stop, pathfinding issues persisted, and an achievement was awarded even when I did not earn it (thanks though!). For some reason, the game's graphics looked more dated than that of 'KOTOR', and some character models looked weird with their bug-eyed appearance. Plus, I had issues with the game's pacing as it took an unnecessarily long time for it to get interesting. Why do I again need to play a Jedi who has to relearn the Force, and wait so long to pick up a lightsaber? I played 'KOTOR' already, just let me get to the good stuff!

Datedness aside, I cannot wholeheartedly recommend 'KOTOR II' given how unpolished it is. Given how one needs to devote much time to truly take in all the rich content the game has to offer, I cannot even recommend curious gamers to give it a quick go to see if they'd like it, especially when it takes many hours before the game starts to get somewhat interesting. Fans of 'Star Wars' Legends (formerly Expanded Universe) may be able to overlook the unresolved bugs and antiquated graphics to enjoy 'KOTOR II'; sadly, I could not.

reviewText:
In general everyone seems to think KoTOR is better than TSL. I am not among the general.

That said, TSL has some buggy stuff where suddenly you and all your people are Sith aligned. CTDs. The script language does not always make sense, and the paths forward are not always clear. The said, the scope here is almost as impressive as the philosophy.

You are again a mysterious stranger. You don't wait as long to find out who you are. Mentored by an old Jedi, once again you assemble a team and make choices. Some of these forward your relationship to gain character backstory. Some of these increase your leanings. Again, you decide how you want to play: Kill 'em all and let the force sort them out, be at peace with anything that doesn't aggro you, or meh.

The depth of the story, though, is impressive. There is betrayal, Jedi gone rogue, some dude who is literally falling apart after trying to kill his master, and a boss that consumes the force for sustenance. They all tie-in to the greater story explored in the novels of who is Revan, was he good or bad (or she, again, the canon is overthrown), and what force exists beyond what can be seen by the Jedi council that threatens all of Republic space? You can also help rebuild" the Mandalorians
recommended: and destroy a planet. It's really cool. Toss in the restored content and other mods (just like KoTOR)
hoursPlayed: and you've got serious replayability.\n\nrecommended buy

reviewText:
TL;DR: Beautifully made game, deep story. Fixes below. You're all meatbags. All hail the Gizka's.

Absolutely one of my most favorite games of all time (and I play many games). This game is a gem of both RPG's and the star wars universe because of the amazing depth in storytelling and the way it engages me and allows me to make my own choices, something I've found lacking in games recently. Originally I owned both KOTORs on xbox (and shamelessly logged  hundreds  of hours into each) and rebought them on steam for the third time (original disk broke) just to play it again.

---What you need to know---
Yes, the game is buggy. This was made for much earlier versions of windows and you're likely to suffer the odd glitch every now and then. HOWEVER there is, of course, a fix! A few of the catch-all fixes that I've used and have worked for the PC versions are as follows;
The  swconfig  file which can be found in your game folder installation directory. Open this and check 1) Enable Hardware Mouse and 2) Disable Movies. You miss a little disabling movies and so you may want to go back and uncheck it and see whether it works for you. Last resort you can watch them through the main menu or through the magic of the internet.
Editing the swkotor2" configuration file
date: found in the same directory. Should fullscreen not work out for you as it didnt for me then paste the following line below [Graphics Options] --> AllowWindowedMode=1\nThen change the "Fullscreen=1" to "Fullscreen=0" and you'll be playing in windowed mode.\nEnabling compatability mode. Not difficult to do
recommended: which compatability you use depends on your system.The internet is your friend! By no means is this a comprehensive list
hoursPlayed: just the major ones that I've confirmed to work for myself or others.\n\nTruly this is a fantastic game and easily worth its price. Also look out for the Restored Content mod
voteText: which flushes out the story to its true potential and adds so much great stuff to the game! Now quit sitting around and buy the game already meatbags."

reviewText:
Well, I just powered through my first playthrough, after putting it off for quite a long time. I completed KOTOR 1 a long time ago, and to the day it is a dearly beloved game to me.

Some general pros and cons:

Pros:

-Turn-based gameplay with an active pause system (very handy)
-Lots of cool Star Wars lore (and if you don't like that, you can skip through almost all of it)
-More weapons/armor than the first game
-A wide variety of sidequests
-Karmic system: Be a nice guy or a scary madman (Darkside and lightside, baby)

Cons:
- Not a specific spoiler, but you choose if you want to see it: it will affect your attitude towards the rest of the game.  The ending. WTF?! So so so so many loose ends...
-A decent number of weird bugs. However, quite a few can be corrected by workshop content
-Space suit animation doe
-It's not the prettiest game out there, but it'll do
-Balacing issues, in turns of battle gameplay. It seems to roller coaster throughout the game

I can't say I loved this game quite as much as the first KOTOR. I really wanted to like it as much as the first, but it fell short. I would recommend checking out the restored content mods in the workshop to make the game better overall, I wasn't aware that they existed until after I finished my playthrough, so before playing I would definitely install that.

I would give it a 8/10 overall. I want to be more critical, but I can't without going in-depth about the game's content (I don't like to spoil).

reviewText:
This game brings back some serious nostalgia. It was one of the first RPG's I ever played and help solidify my passion for Star Wars. If you played the orginal and enjoyed it than this game is for you. If not...its made some marginal improvements but it isn't drastically different than the first.

PROS
More complicated morality system. Makes you question wheter your actions are truly good or evil.

Intriguing story filled with twists and turns.

Likable companions.

A large variety of force powers and feats to choose from.
CONS
Somewhat glitchy.

Terrible AI.

Severely limited unless The Siths Lord Restored Content Mod is installed.
Overall I would reccomend this game to anyone who like the orginal KOTOR and any Star Wars fan. I would suggest downloading The Sith Lords Restored Content Mod from the workshop for the optimal experience. If either of these apply I would wholeheartily reccomend this addition to your library.

I was particularly overjoyed by the lightsaber forms as I felt Obsidian had paid close attention to the Star Wars lore and each form brought something new to the table and promoted a more strategic approach to fights.

Story wise, I felt Obsidian made an impressive story but it did feel a little too cryptic and convoluted at times and I have to admit that the first game set the bar very high with the amazing twist which this game lacked. However, the characters were astounding and I loved the Handmaiden's backstory in particular and I could tell that Obsidian had invested a lot of thought and time to make these characters relatable and likeable.

I felt that this game was less bug ridden than it's predecessor and it ran smoother altogether which is always nice even though it wasn't free of bugs entirely as at times some cutscenes skipped for whatever reason. Once again, the choices you make in the game heavily influence what kind of character you become and the interactions you have with your crew and Obsidian proves that KOTOR is one of the best titles when it comes to decision making.

Another triumph by Obsidian here and a more than worthy sequel and I expect more greatness from them in the future.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
ERMEGERD ITS MAH CHILDHOOD!

I played this game waaay back in 2005 on the original Xbox and played it almost religiously. I knew every quest, every conversation, every inch of the Ebon Hawk. The irony is that I played this before the first game, so many of the easter eggs were lost on me.

But now? I played it again and while the graphics certainly haven't aged well, the story is as good as ever. I played with the Restored Content Mod and wow! This game is more alive than ever. The heart of this game lies not with the combat, but with the conversations you have, learning about the Force and the philosophy of the Jedi and Sith. This game accomplishes with a few talks with Kreia more than what Episodes 1-3 could in their combined runtimes.

If you play this game, it is a must to get the Restored Content Mod as it brings the game to its full potential. All the broken plot lines are fixed. The crew all have more flow to them. Most of the bugs are gone (I stress most).

I played the game as a Jedi Master, and boy do you feel more like a Jedi than the ones you're looking for. I suspect the same could be said if you go dark side, which is what I plan to do after I finish my first playthrough. Yeah, I'm 50 hours in and still not done one playthrough. All of your crew have full storyarchs and backstories. You get to know all of them and have a hand in their future. Interestingly, I somehow managed to turn HK-47 into the pinnacle light side character despite his insistance on murdering the crew.

That said, remember when I stressed that MOST of the bugs were fixed? Currently I am unable to continue as I've encountered a bug that breaks the controls. Hopefully its just a one-time thing but I lost an hour because of it. You've been warned.

As for the combat, it's alright. It's not the worst thing ever, but it's nowhere near the best. Sure it looks pretty, and the combat moves are really varied, but it does feel clunky with the way it works.

If you're a Star Wars fan, this game and its original are a must-own. Together they form the backbone of the lore for Star Wars. There is a reason they are held in such high regard.

reviewText:
This game is an interesting beast.
Obsidian was rushed during the developing of the game and was forced to release it without fulfilling their vision of the game, and thus it has a LOT of missing content.
Thankfully, there is a mod that restores some of the content that was cut from the game, and trust me, it really improves the experience and fills a lot of holes in the story.
If for some godly reason you decide that you want the vanilla experience, well, it's still a good game, but missing vast chunks that by the end of the game make you feel like you somehow missed some of the story.
With the restored content mod this game becomes a solid 10/10
Without it it's an 8/10
Visas best waifu.

reviewText:
I have heard a lot of people say that this one does not even compare to the original... I strongly disagree. So far, this one is BETTER than the original. In the following ways especially:
- Allows you to CREATE items and not simply and only upgrade. Although you can do that to and the variety of upgrades are much larger too.
- Walking around is much easier, A and D actually turn your character now.
- The graphics are MUCH better should you adjust your settings accordingly.
- Swoop racing is much more fun.
- Combat mechanics have drastically improved.
- Looting things is a lot nicer. It will tell you if something is empty on your screen so that you know you have been there already.
- There are three options for hacking/slicing things. You can either slice, bash, or you can use an explosive which really simplifies things.
- There are more but I do not want to take the time to list them.

I have been very impressed with this game so far and look forward to progressing through it.

reviewText:
WHat can I possibly say about KOTOR that hasn't been said yet?
This game and KOTOR 1 are, to me, possibly the best games in the SW-franchise.
I love the setting, thousands of years before the events in the movies. They did well with the vibe and stuff.

However, please keep in mind that these games are rather old. They did work well on Steam (while the version I bought at a store and installed from a DVD required a ton of fiddling until they actually worked). They are not looking great anymore, but if you are into the story, check this out... it's such a fun story with a big twist/surprise (which of course, by now, everyone knows about).

It's not quite as much fun when you play through it again, even though you can go for a different class, but the whole storyline, visiting those iconic places, unravelling the secrets is a ton of fun.
one of the best RPGs ever for me, and if you don't mind playing very outdated (graphically) games, and you like SW and/or RPGs, make sure to get this!

reviewText:
if your game crashes this will help.
C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Knights of the Old Republic II\swkotor2.ini
Go to the config file and type in:
AllowWindowedMode=1
Then, wherever it says, Fullscreen=1, change it to zero. Bam. KotOR II works on Windows 7
Thanks FRott

reviewText: I played this game when it first came out on the XBox many years ago when it first came out, and like the first game, I loved it. When this appeared during the holiday sale, I decided I ought to have it on a current device and snatched it up. The game and story are still every bit as engrossing as I remember them, but I find the lack of controller support to be super-annoying. Furthermore, perhaps it is just my laptop, but graphical issues abound. I can't Alt-Tab without the program crashing (which means that any time I adjust the volume it crashes); it also crashes frequently during cutscenes. I am sure I could rectify some of these issues with some internet research and some editing of the .ini file, but I don't think I should HAVE to do that. I sort of expect the games to, y'know... work.\n\nThe game itself is to be recommended, but I really have to grit my teeth and put up with the lackluster port.

reviewText:
SW:KOTOR 2 is an RPG game Developed by Obsidian Entertainment. The game takes place  a few years after the events of KOTOR 1 after Revan defeated Malak and saved the galaxy. But now after departed deep into the outer rim of the galaxy, a bunch of Sith Lords, have appeared and have almost completly destoryed the Jedi order and the remaining Jedi Masters are into hiding. You play as a male or female Jedi Exile which you learn later into the game about why you were exiled from the Jedi Order. After escaping a Mine Fuel facuilty (Either by blowing it up and evading a sith ship) you head to a orbiting facilty above a planet called Telos. After being imprisoned and captured by them you find out the ship you traveled in, the Ebon Hawk has been stolen. After helping a light or dark side corporation and meeting a soldier that knows your character, you travel to many places into the planet until you get your ship back after finding out a Jedi Master lives in a acdemy in a polar region of the planet. After a companion gets the data base at the academy you find out why, your charcter was exiled and leaves you between two roads: Do you gather up the rest of the Masters to help you fight the sith, or do you join the sith and hunt down and kill the Jedi Masters?

The companions you meet are all cool and deep. They all have secrets behind them which you have to get them to trust you to find out. Some of them you may not enjoy (like a stupid robot that is a jerk), but alot of them are fun to talk too, a few of them were in KOTOR 1 that make a return like T3-M4 and HK-47.

One of the highlights of this game is the Light and Dark side paths. Through multiple parts of the game you sometimes given a choice such as kill an innocent by raiding his house then kill him as he returns (Dark Side) or saving someone from mercneary thugs (Light Side).

The gameplay is a turn base or real time action (Can be chosen through menu) game. The game has powers that are ran by a 1d20 system. I'm stupid so I don't know much about the system but if you know stuff from Dungeons & Dragons you might understand it. The level cap is to belive is 30 but that doesnt mean its easy and should be taken lightly. Like how Fallout 3 and NV take a while so does this. This also means you want to spend Attributes when making a character very carefully as messing up might make it harder to clear the game. For example: putting alot of points into Constitution and Intelligence might give alot of VP and skill points to use, but at the cost of FP (force points) which might make it harder for you to use force powers.

OVerall KOTOR 2 is a fun game, with it just getting workshop, people can get the restored content mod and get the true and perhaps best parts of the game. Problem is sometimes that game can be difficult with what planets you decide to visit and there are some annoying puzzles. I find the 10$ to be worth it but if you would like try to get it during a sale...

This game gets a 9/10 - A fun and amazing game but with some minors problems.
