reviewText:
The devs at Obsidian Entertainment have always been exceptional storytellers. Despite this game being 10 years old, KOTOR 2 has memorable NPC's, an epic yet personal story, and great characterization and atmosphere. The main complaint (rightly deserved) that people had with this game was that it was originally released in a buggy, obviously rushed state. But that was several years ago. Today with The Sith Lords Restored Content Mod (TSLRCM) available on the Steam Workshop, we can experience KOTOR 2 as it was meant to be played. It's amazing.

Here are some of the things that TSLRCM does:

1) It fixes 99% of the bugs that Obsidian never got around to fixing. This allows Obsidian's excellent story to really shine.

2) Cut content from quests and cutscenes have been restored. This enriches the story and makes the characters' motivations *much* clearer.

3) HD Widescreen resolution support. You will have to seek out other mods to get higher resolution textures, though.

reviewText: A good game, and great fun to mess around in.  The story is a huge improvement over the already impressive Knights of the Old Republic, and almost everything else feels like a decent upgrade.    If you're looking for a game like KOTOR, but have played KOTOR till it's become a bit boring, this is what you want.\n\nA brief note: I did use the fan mod, I don't know how much of an effect that had but it was highly reccomended.  The game has aged quite a bit graphically.  It's also probably *not* worth a second playthrough: my playtime notwithstanding (I suspect a lot of it is while the game was running but I was doing something else), most of your enjoyment of the story will be in its twists and turns.  Choosing radically different dialogue options will affect your character build and force powers, but it probably won't make playing the same thing again much more interesting.

reviewText:
What can I say?.. It's good 'ol KOTOR.. Not as polished as the first, but that's what The Sith Lords: Restored Content Mod is for. Download that and you will be set to start on your tale of heriosm or villiany in a broken galaxy far, far away..

This game is a fantastic addition to the KOTOR family and sadly the last. It improves upon much of the mechanics of the first KOTOR, adds a great cast of new and some old companions, nice locations to visit, and a great continuation of the storyline we loved.

Sadly, you can feel how frenzied they were to get this out the door. In it's unmodded state it is lacking both in a finished story and 2-3 extra planets/missions. It was cast aside when it was released but, years later it has made a triumphant return and finally got the love and attetion it deserved from a great community of players and modders.

In summary 7.5/10 in release-state and 9/10 with the restored content mod. So go ahead an pick this up for yourself and make sure to download TSL:RCM.

reviewText:
KOTOR 2 is one of the several tales of what could have been when it comes to video games getting rushed out by the publisher; but what we do have with the Restoration Mod is still good.

KOTOR 2 is probably the most interesting Star Wars story; it takes everything about the series lore on the Force, the Jedi, and the Sith and breaks them down, satirizing the stark black and white morality that the series had fallen into because of those concepts. This idea is personified in one character and that character is probably one of the best characters in video games. KOTOR 2 also actually manages to have in-universe explanations for some of the gameplay elements and it’s really well done.

KOTOR 2 is not without flaws however. I found the combat to be a horrendous slog so I actively cheated my way to get to the really good parts, the roleplaying and story. While one specific character is really interesting and likable, the rest of your party is mostly more flat and aren't as good as the party members in say Planescape or Nier. Regardless I'd say it’s still worth playing and at the very least you should check out a Let's Play because KOTOR 2 really is cool.

reviewText:
+ impressive story which isn't so black or white as the first KOTOR, backed up by extensive dialogues
+ high level cap which can't be achieved by normal playing (opposed to maximum level 20 in the first KOTOR)
+ many quests, skills, force powers etc. and many alternative ways which a player can take
+ gameplay which takes between 30-50 hours to finish
+ Kreia, hands down to one of the best written game characters

- even with TSLRCM there are some minor bugs
- some NPCs you're travelling with are rather uninteresting, but I guess that's depends on one's taste


Play original KOTOR first if you're thinking of buying this game and haven't played the prequel yet.

If you liked the prequel then go for KOTOR 2 with no hesitation. With the TSL Restored Content Mod the game is almost as good as the first KOTOR and makes much more sense than it did at the time of the rushed release.

Read this if you're interested in some 'behind the scenes' of KOTOR sequels.

reviewText:
(PROTIP: If you plan to buy KOTOR 2 for PC, you should, beyond a reasonable doubt, download and install the Restored Content mod. Since Obsidian rushed KOTOR 2's release for the holiday season, they had to cut out parts of this game, most of which were pretty integral to the plot.)

Synopsis: You, the player, are The Exile (canonically a woman named Meetra Surik). Like many of your fellow Jedi, you followed Revan to help the Republic during the Mandalorian Wars. Revan, who was impressed with your combat prowess, decided to appoint you as one of his top generals.

The final battle of the Mandalorian Wars took place near the Sith planet of Malachor V. Since the rest of the Republic's fleet could make it to the battle in time, you decide to utilize the Republic's ultimate weapon: The Mass Shadow Generator, designed by the Zabrak technician Bao-Dur. The Mass Shadow Generator activates, pulling the planet, the Mandalorian armada and the Republic fleet into a gravity field. The death of the planet and all parties involved was so great that it gave you a Wound in The Force, severing and deafening your connection to The Force.

However, unlike the rest of your Jedi colleagues, you were the only one who did not fall to the Dark Side. When the war was over, you decided to return to the Jedi Council on Coruscant to face judgement. The Council, both butt furious over your insubordination and incredulous at your voluntary return unanimously chose to banhammer you from The Order. You were then exiled to wander the outer reaches of the Galaxy. Oh, and they took your lightsaber as well.
-

Fast forward five years later. The war with Darth Malak and the Sith was so costly the Republic can barely defend itself. Strange, phantom-like Sith assassins have dogged the Jedi, hunting them down in an effort to completely destroy the Jedi Order. The crime syndicate known as The Exchange" has put out a bounty for any live Jedi. Strange

reviewText:
Hands down one of the best Starwars game out there, great graphics for the fact it's a 2005 game, it has a great system itself and lot's of different choices and a great modding community.

Pros:
- Has both light/dark side choices
- Can train companions to be jedi's
- Great indepth story with restored content mod
- Amazing graphics for when it was made
- Good combat system
- Fun to replay and find out the different light/dark endings

Cons:
-Repetitive Fights
-Mobs don't respawn once they die it's over you can't power level
-Endgame when the game ends its over you can't do anything else but sit there and watch the credits
-Might be annoying at some points since it's difficult, not as bad when you load up a lot of mods.
-Has some annoyig bugs sometimes where you can get stuck or game can crash etc.

Overall I rate this game 7/10 without mods 9/10 with mods, it's a great game and a great RPG I really recomend it.

reviewText:
Only the greatest CRPG of all time! No, really.

Well, maybe if you value things like 'not having bugs' or 'balanced gameplay' or 'not being rushed out the door for Christmas'. But, what classic CRPG (Bioware aside) isn't filled with these little character flaws? Frankly, it still feels more polished than Alpha Protocol, which, while remaining one of my favorite all-time games, doesn't have the 'rushed out' excuse so much.

Despite being a licenced game and sequel, the story of the Jedi Exile and her companions (oh, did I mention the player character is canonically female?) manages to have the best narrative I've seen in any video game I've ever played, one which still sparks debate over its true messages and intent. Without giving too much away, you'll be touching on the nature of good and evil, the scars that remain from war, the struggle against objective morality and appointed fate, and the very real consequences that come from being a video game character. (No, really.)

Also, this game both stands up to repeat paythroughs and doesn't make you hate the vast majority of the supporting cast. (LOOKING AT YOU, BIOWARE)

More importantly, thanks to the good people at Aspyr and the dedicated mod community, the game has both the content it deserved to ship with and a slick control and graphical update for the modern gamer. Fully playable using a 360 controller, widescreen without stretching or patch hacks, and on whichever operating system you fancy most. (IN YOUR FACE, BIOWARE)

Star Wars love not required, and perhaps detrimental! Being a person who hates Star Wars, I have to make the obvious admission that some fans of that saga might not like this game too much. That said, the depths of the story and its themes, and the ambiguity they bring, should make up for that...and to be sure, this game still packs a lot of love for the old hokey science-fantasy epic, all the same. (Also, I love other Star Wars games too, like the original Battlefront titles, so don't get too uppity.)

TL;DR Made me a nihilist, Handmaiden best girl, 11/10.

reviewText:
Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic - The Sith Lords.

I am recommending this game because not only does it master everything a good RPG should have, but it manages to do it in the Star Wars atmosphere. What I am trying to address is that TSL delivers an unforgettable, dark, mysterious experience. The story in Kotor 2 is just breathtaking and fascinating, it conveys us the most intriguing remarkable characters a video game can offer. This game really allows you to get attached to the extraudinary characters and adventures along the way of the story. Though the TSLRCM is a MUST have in order to get the full TSL experience. My personal oppinion is that Kotor 2 TSL definately exceeds the first game in almost every aspect, especially with the TSLRCM. Kotor 1 just simply did not have that eroding dark mysterious feel about it. In Kotor 2 the interaction with companions is also much more interesting; the way you can influence and decieve them into either learning the ways of jedi or sith. Kotor 2 TSL is simply a masterpeice.

Even if you aren't into Star Wars you WILL be happy with this game.

reviewText:
This game is one of my favorite games out of all the Star Wars games I have played. A lot of people will tell you how broken and buggy it is, but in all honesty, I blame Obsidian. They have a history of taking great games and copy/pasting them into a new game with some extra stuff and a ton of bugs (*cough cough* Fallout: New Vegas *cough cough*). Basically, that is what this game is. It plays just like the original, looks just like the original, and is just as great as the original. This is not what most want out of a sequel. I was disappointed at first by the lack of originality and lack of new looks and feels. It was more of a big expansion. The same game as the first.

But while I sit here and make the game sound awful, worry not! It actually is a fantastic game. The game's story takes you on a journey across a bunch of awesome planets (I <3 the Onderon/Dxun stuff) and the dialogue is extremely well written. Each character has a huge and deep past that you can figure out as you travel with them and watch them react to your actions. Mandalore might think you are a stupid runt that could never be as great as those damn Mandalorians for giving some credits to a beggar, but Visas might think that it is a noble and beautiful act. Maybe Atton, who used to hate when you were cruel to people, now relishes in every innocent victim you slaughter for no apparent reason (Yo, dawg, the Force has no power in Hell, so go Light Side or go home). Shaping the will of others is an incredible part of this game that you can make different each time you play it.

All in all, the game is incredible. If you can acually get the game to start up properly, actually avoid all of the grass block bugs on Dxun and Dantooine, and avoid the annoying dialogue skipping glitches (which can be avoided by taking a break from the game and booting it up after a walk in some sunlight), you are going to really enjoy yourself with this masterpiece of a game. You don't have to play the first one, but I recommend doing that because it also has a story and writing to die for. I'm a sucker for good video game dialogue. Get out there and kill some Sith Lords.

reviewText:
This game is one of the most moving pieces of Star Wars history.  Kreia your wanabe teacher says very true statements that you are actually lulled into trusting her judgements (that are VERY worth listening too).  You also can change the personalities of the people you travel with by just talking to them in a positive or negative fashion (reinforced by your alignment (Jedi or Sith)).

This game actually makes me feel more intelligent by Kreia's speaches and opinions.  She also reveals a great deal about backstory and possible future events at <removed due to spoilers>.

The gameplay itself is actually pretty nice.  It has a lot of combat options and things you can personalize.  Whether you want to fight with a lightsaber or not.  The armor you wear can compliment your characters abilities, and your companions aren't typical support characters.  They actually add some welcome and very real context to the game, as well as great combat efficiency.

As for the level designs they could be better, but they remain pleasing to look at.  Even with the polygons that the game had to work with (considering it was put on an older disk).

Also the companions never feel dull because they actually go and talk to each other.  Their conflicts add to the suspence.  Their personalities actually collide, and in the end every mission is a real experience with each of them.  Hell each one has specially added dialog for whenever you use them.  (keep in mind this data is still all compact in an older disk).

All in all?  Worth it.  Story is great, characters are inspired, gameplay feels good, and it leaves an impression on you.

reviewText: Although unpolished and perhaps incomplete (unless you manage to set up the Restored Content Mod), Knights of the Old Republic II is a masterpiece, a great RPG which condenses unconventional Star Wars themes into a Star Wars game. It is one of a kind, and a must for pretty much any RPG enthusiast. The writing is what really drives this game forward, and each sentence carries a depth of meaning that few other games can be proud of offering and that therefore contributes to the grandiosity of this title.

reviewText: Bioware passes the torch to Obsidian Entertainment where Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic II - The Sith Lords is born (TSL). During the initial release, Obsidian faced criticism over the game's abrupt ending which was later blamed on LucasArts's unwavering timeline for a holiday release. Fortunately for fans--from fans!--there is an essential modification to download to restore most of the cut content named, The Sith Lords Restored Content Mod (TSLRCM). The game itself features a much darker atmosphere and expands on everything that made the original game great so this sequel is a must for fans.

reviewText:
This game genuinely suprised me. I was deeply in love with the first game, but I never  could get into this game because of all it's bugs and glitches.. until now. I HIGHLY recommend playing the game with The Sith Lords: Restored Content Mod, because it adds so, SO much more content to the game that should of made it to the final cut.

The characters, oh my god, the characters.. Intriguiging backgrounds, wonderful dialog. The places.. To see places previously seen, previously unknown, remastered and in some cases, made, is just.. wonderful. The main story is amazing, IMO, even though others seem to disagree. The choices truly make you feel like you are doing a good thing or a bad thing, and the music adds to that. The music also makes the game much better, with atmosphere and such. The beauty in KOTOR games is that you can play through them twice, Good and Bad. Even then, you still miss a heap of content without realizing. I haven't even mentioned the characters that you have seen in the past play a fairly huge chunk of the story, which is amazing.

I used to be of the opinion that this game was horrible compared the the first one, but that is because I encountered countless game breaking bugs, because I was playing without the previously mentioned mod. Now, I am of the opinion that this game is almost as good as the original. The only things that make the original better are: 1. It's Revan's Storyline, for peats sake! 2. More polished 3. It's the original!

All in all, this was a wonderful sequel, amazing Star Wars game, and you should have it in your library, like, RIGHT now.

Get this game or Nilhius will anhiliate Earth. :)

reviewText:
Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic was a good roleplaying game developed by Bioware. KOTOR 2, the sequel, was developed by Obsidian. The core differences here is that Obsidian still legitimately cares about making a good stat based RPG and not a shooter with romance options. I think I'm projecting modern Bioware shortcomings here but KOTOR 2 took everything that was wrong with the original and tried very hard to fix it. The game is by no means perfect, and you WILL need to download one of the Restoration Project mods to fix bugs and add content that was cut but as a role-playing game KOTOR 2 is still absolutely great.

Your choices matter, the whole game is seeing how the consequences of your choices play out. This whole game is about choice. The characters are excellent, the writing is everything you would expect of an Obsidian title. The game almost starts out as a satire of Bioware cliches but quickly becomes its own animal, allowing you to explore a deeper aspect of the morality of the Star Wars universe that a lot of games never do.

While this game certainly is not perfect, I find it better than the original in nearly every way. That said, I do recommend playing the original before you ever get started on this, the original game is still a good title and deserves the respect its earned. There are better RPG's out there, but you won't find a lot of them on Steam yet. For what it is this game is great and I love playing it.

8/10 would play again.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Both KotOR games are buggy.  There's no doubt.  This one is the buggier one, God have mercy.

BUT there are mods to help that and restore unfinished content that are quite easy to install.  Just make sure you only have one, maybe two, major bug fix mods.  In my experience they will start to conflict with each other.

Now, bugs aside, this is some of the best Star Wars storytelling I've ever witnessed.  Better than KotOR 1 me thinks.  What I like most is that it focuses on the mysticism of the Force and character interaction.  While there is still the simple Light/Dark side meter from the first game, it almost seems to be more of a ploy than anything.  An action may net you Light Side points, but now your influence on your companions is a factor.

If you want to bring a teammate to the Light, you have to have influence.  But your goody two shoes actions might put them off, driving further towards whatever side you are not.  On top of that, the narrative will keep suggesting that the whole notion of Light/Dark is shallow and inaccurate to how the events of the game play out.  It doesn't try to throw out the notion of good and bad, but it tries to make you think twice about what is actually a good action and what is a bad action.

reviewText:
At the relatively young age of 25 I find this game makes me feel like a wrinkled old senile. I can't tell you how many times I played this game on that old black box with the giant X on it. I fell in love with the first game and was a little dissapointed with the initial release of the sequel. Something felt unfinished and I could never explain it until I read it was basically rushed out a year after the first one to get it out in time for Christmas. Pieces of the game were cut and unfinished just to cash in on Santa Clause. Even with its faults it was an extremely enjoyable game when it was released.

I tried every build I could think of, saved before conversations to see every possible story ark, and completed the game as light, dark, and neutral. During the playing of both games in the series I must have filled up the old xbox hard drive several times a runthrough. It was just that good and the possiblities of the storylines seemed endless.

Fast forward to today and some beutiful people from the internet have created a patch that finishes the missing content of the game, and a second patch that adds in a planet that from what I understand had some minor pieces of data lodged somewhere in the game but is mostly filled in with the patch team's own storyline. I have to say I can't tell so far what is from the patch I installed and what is the original game, but it feels damn good to play through this story again. And I'm looking forward to seeing the finished content.

This game was a strong piece of the last years of my childhood and I can't tell you how much it means to me. While it is true the sequel to Bioware's KOTOR is made by Obsidian it feels very much like a Bioware game of its period.The game uses a modified version of the original Bioware engine and it is well documented that the two companies had done work together during this period. Maybe it's something to do with EA buying out Bioware, but it feels like Bioware is not the same company it used to be. Replaying KOTOR 1&2 and playing Jade Empire for the first time I can see some huge differences between what Bioware once was and the Bioware of today with its ME trilogy, DA series, and SWTOR. While the new Bioware games are very good in their own right I feel like the company has lost a little bit of something wonderful in its current lineup. Other than the Mass Effect trilogy I don't feel like I have the interest to finish games such as DA or SWTOR (Not that one can really ever finish an MMO); not to say that I don't like the newer work from the company I would just prefer they focus on a true sequel to KOTOR over milking the Dragon Age series for everything they can get.

If you have any interest in Bioware's current lineup do yourself a favor and give the Knights of the Old Republic series a chance. The series is definitely showing its age but it's still just as well made as anything from the magic Canadian elves who work at Bioware.

reviewText:
As a legend this game promises the dream of a titanic stuggle, an endless journey in the Galaxy.
The surprise comes however when we discover how deep some concepts are taken. The Force is more present then ever.

I have to say that I played with the Restored Content Mod through my playthrough and it can be downloaded here: http://www.moddb.com/mods/the-sith-lords-restored-content-mod-tslrcm

Despite the fixes the game crashed a couple of times, there were occasional glitches and bugs. Was it worth it?

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MJuZ3hZjxdI

Knights of the Old Republic is often reffered to as simply KOTOR.
This is an often overlooked game because even after fixes it's still rather unstable and unpredictable. The possibility to see the world after KOTOR 1 though pays off in it's own way!
Everything remained almost the same since the last game. The Bioware style of doing things persists and shows a deep understanding of RPG game mechanics. It is a solid experience in combat and common storytelling alike.

It's not by Bioware anymore...

The unique traits of an Obsidian title though show after getting more companions and interacting with them. Similar to Mass Effect, Dragon Age.
You posses influence over them, she politely refuses to share life stories until there is more trust between you (gained usually by expressing views similar to theirs). As you go along though, these stories are revealead simply through spending time together and showing what a charismatic individual you are.

The story told is worth of an entire essay on it's own.
By getting to the bottom of it - the proportions of it seem to always lead toward a gigantic revelation, one step ahead of a mystery, great conspiracy - respectively a fitting end.
Without spoiling anything I will say that I never expected Star Wars to go so deeply into the philosophy of the Force. Good and evil are simple. There are characters in this game however that twist it into a novel thing altogether.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XKYVuMhxfMA&index

My feelings on the game are mixed. It definately feels rushed towards the end. The restored levels don't seem to be worth it from the mods. But despite that the journey is as they say, reward enough for that.


Should you get it?

Play it for the great and cryptic introduction. Assuming that with imagination you can get past the long prologue.
Enjoy it's detailed worlds, tours across a couple of planets, guides into ways to shape the Republic.
Reminisce on KOTOR 1 across 2 planets and with a couple of characters.
From the beggining of KOTOR 2 there is a tone of urgency of some unseen threat. I had the impression the game ended at a cliffhanger that, hopefully was not the original intention.
Despite that, the characters introduced were strong enough for this to be a game worth your money. It is an RPG shifting much closer towards the character and story driven decision-making seen often today.

Play KOTOR 1 and 2 for the full experience!

reviewText:
Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic 2 takes place 5 years after the events of the first. We now play as “The Exile”, a jedi cast out of the order for going to war without the councils permission. As luck would have it he/she is one of the last jedi after the Sith's successful purge and has a huge bounty on his/her head. The situation really shows in game as a good amount of people will try to kill you or deceive you for that huge bounty. It does become a tad tiresome when the same assassin droids show up time and time again spouting the same dialogue each time.  As for the game itself it plays it very safe and only improves upon a few things while keeping everything from the original intact. It is not made by the same developers as the original.

Companions are far improved in this game and now feature a influence system in which they either disprove of you or like you  depending on the actions you take.  This time around there is a much better balance between Light Side and Dark Side companions unlike the original where near everyone had a holier than thou attitude. You never trust any of them either which I found very neat as I half expected the people that have my back to turn on me any moment. Some will flat out refuse to talk to you ever again if you annoy them enough. I still would like the option to kick teammates out of my ship. Which brings me to the ship, it is the same exact ship from the first game. They reuse a lot of material from the first game including planets that are ruin down but the same exact places as the original and much smaller.

They really took a huge step back when it comes to environments. Where as the first game had huge unique environments this one has small gray corridor after small gray corridor. Your choices in the last game doesn't really make a lick of difference and they even get the gender of the 1st game's protagonist wrong and they will default to being female. Not a big deal at all but slightly annoying.  This sequel is far more prone to glitches and crashes. I actually had to cheat to get past a game breaking bug.  It has this incomplete feel as if they either rushed the game out or just didn't care.  It does have a few improvements like your teammate AI is much better at following you around, a small improvement to inventory menus though they are still awful and regenerating health which is neither a good or bad feature.

Gameplay is pretty much the same as the original but with a few different force powers. I don't think they reused any music and it sounds just as amazing as the first.  You now seem to level up much faster and when I was done with the tutorial I was already half the level of the lasts game's character which I had at level 20 by the end of the game. Same abilities, same skills  and same stats as the first, they didn't really do anything to enhance character building. Story is pretty cool and feels much more mysterious than the first. There is no clear good and evil side in this game which is a huge improvement from the first. You never receive a lightsaber either, you have to build it if you want one. Overall I enjoyed the story more than the originals even though I saw the ending coming from a mile away unlike the first.

I mentioned the first a lot in this review but it cant be helped. This sequel is pretty much a carbon copy of the first with a new story and a few highly uninteresting new worlds. It felt like an unnecessary sequel since the last game ended so well and this  game does nothing to enhance the  last game's overall story or makes any improvements to gameplay. Though if you enjoyed the last game and wanted more then it is nearly guaranteed you will love this.  It is definitely more of the same but if that is what you want than this would be a great purchase.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Obsidian is, as usual, the master of making great games that also suck.

To preface, I did generally enjoy KOTOR 2.  But the combat is still unchanged and as hilariously unbalanced as the first game.  I played through with a Jedi Consular and obliterated everything as soon as I had the Force Lightning tree available to me.  To boot, as a Dark Sider with Force Crush, all I had to for all the end game bosses was literally stand perfectly still and spam that power over and over again.  It deals ridiculous amounts of damage, disables the target and is irresistable, meaning you effectively stop them from responding so long as you have force points.  And you can get a looooooot of +Max force point and regeneration upgrades.

And then, jarringly, there are some sections of the game that are stupidly difficult and for all the wrong reasons.  See, if you're like me, you won't spend time optimizing every single party member with the best gear and character builds.  You'll probably have a few favorites you take out.  A lot of the companions, mechanically, are simply redundant.  So when there are sections of the game that FORCE you to play as a SPECIFIC character that you have not paid any attention to, you're in for a terrible time.  At one point I had to beat two melee mini-bosses with Atton.  Atton, who's only real combat strengths involve creeping up and dealing sneak attack damage.  Of course, you don't get to creep up for this fight.  You just start with two Twi'lek bounty hunters breathing down your neck.  I had to cheese that section with mines.

This game is also a technical mess, even with the recent update.  With my card (AMD R9 200 series) and V-sync on I experienced egregiously distracting frame stutters.  But with V sync turned off, you encounter a bug where your character freezes after finishing combat unless you save/reload.  Thankfully this latter bug is only prevalent for the first few hours of the game for some reason, but it's still worth noting.  Other people have reported many other technical problems, and the game still crashes every so often.

Finally, the story.  This is what you're really here for after all.  The narrative does deliver on most fronts; it's chock full of Star Wars lore and you basically get to experience several events that are considered canonical (although your choices may not be).  The characters are well written and there are a lot of choices to make.  My only gripe with the story was the ending.  Simply put, the ending felt rushed and unfinished.  This might be because I played with the Restored Content mod, but I can't imagine that not having that mod would do anything but make this problem worse.  There are certain cutscenes that are simply not followed upon.  A string of events happens near the last hour of the game and it's never really explained how or why.  I still don't know what happened to most of my companions by the time the credits rolled.  There was only some closure for a couple, with the rest seemingly forgotten about.  It was an underwhelming ending, and really, it just felt unfinished.  Both from a narrative standpoint and from a mechanical one (empty dull corridor after empty dull corridor full of bad guys to Force Storm.)

KOTOR 2 is really the apposite Obsidian game to inform of the stereotype; flawed in just about every aspect, but with redeeming qualities in each, and still enjoyable as a whole.  At about 30-something mostly enjoyable hours for a playthrough, it's still worth a recommendation and the 10 dollar admission price.

reviewText: Great game in general and in sequel to one of my favorite games.  I'd recommend this game to anyone that has an affinity for a good party based RPG that has some great dialog and story to it.  This game has the problem of being rushed to release though, most of these quirks were covered up by a restoration mod that I used, e.i. low resolution cut scenes, glitches, even adding back in a whole level, but other than those issues there is the problem of the ending still feeling flat and lacking the depth of the rest of the game.  The ending is the main thing to be suffered from being rushed to released but I don't think that should effect whether or not you buy the game.  If you have played the first Knights of the Old Republic the game play is generally the same but really stands out with great dialog and deep characters.  I feel like there was a bit more adventure in the first one though as far as world and environments, but even with a rushed release I feel the game is still on the level of the first game in many ways.

reviewText:
Holy cheesus. I bought this game waaay back in 2005 when it was released on four disc format, but in true Obsidian form it was a total buggy mess and throughout the years I kept coming up against game breaking bugs, constant crashes, ever corrupting save files and just plain terrible porting. I decided to put the game on indefinate hiatus until I had some spare time to sit and try and figure it out. The time came and I'm pleased to report I actually finally finished this ♥♥♥♥ing thing. However I am rather disapointed, but I now understand why people see KotoR 1 as the better game, and I agree with them.

- Story is a complete convoluted mess. It tries to be far too cryptic and often trips itself up and reveals things it was trying to keep a secret. The ending really doesn't answer anything and everything just sorta trails off and the credits roll...

- Light and Dark side points are really wonky in the way you can gain or lose them, for example: I was playing as a Light Side Jedi, I rescued a child from being sold to spice miners as a slave and returned her to her mother and then declined a reward, that's worthy of Light Side points right? No. I netted NO Light Side points for that. Another example would be: I asked a simple question to one of my party members that seemed innocent enough, yet I earned a ton of Dark Side points for it and got a net Dark Side shift for my trouble.

- Unless you really, really level and spec into ranged characters (blaster rifles / pistols), ranged characters are almost exclusively useless. Melee beats absoluely everything.

+ SYSTEMS FAILING MASTER".

? Everything is super ♥♥♥♥ing cryptic and almost nothing makes sense. Very few of your party characters will open up to you even if you have crazy amouns of influence with them. This sorta makes most characters feel really shallow even if their personalities are different. Only person that really even talked to me was the Handmaiden and that took FOREVER.

? Lots of the powers and feats are all backwards. A lot of them end up never getting used. I was granted Master Force Jump very early on
date:
and I only ever saw it used 3 times in the ENTIRE play through.

- Your party / characters get stuck in combat long after all threats have been destroyed.

- Animations are full ♥♥♥♥♥♥.

- It has aged terribly.

- Doesn't run in 1920x1080 or higher resolutions unless you do some .ini file tampering.

- Crashes a lot.

+ Lightsaber construction and general weapon / armor upgrading is pretty cool. Nice to be able to totally personalise a lightsaber to what you want to use it for.

- The Jedi Masters are total ♥♥♥♥♥. Especially Vrook.

+ The game doesn't hold your hand
recommended: you're largley left to explore things for yourself or consult your journal if you need finer details on what you need to do. However
hoursPlayed: it doesn't help you keep track of side quests very well and you lose a few in translation. But yeah
voteText: not having the Skyrim "X marks the spot QUEST IS HERE
helpfulPercent:
DUMBASS" leaves a lot of the decisions down to the player and has them actively searching around the environment instead of just following the minimap with a big X on it.

Recommended if you enjoy Star Wars and RPGs and you have the time to sit and play it. Not recomended if you're a new comer to RPGs or not a Star Wars fan. Since I'm a Star Wars fan and RPG veteran then I am going to recommend it.

Despite all the negatives I've pointed out. Overall

reviewText:
THIS IS EASILY ONE OF THE GREATEST STAR WARS GAMES EVER:

Star wars knights of the old republic is, in my opinion, the best in the series and has a wonderfull storyline, but these are not the only reasons I love this game so much, yes, I said LOVE.
I, truly love this game because of all of the memories I have playing it, this game has always brought me comfort if I was feeling sad and it will continue to do so. But the reason I love it so much is because of my best friend and the best 5 years of my life.
It all started on Christmas day 2008, I was an excited kid ready to open his gift, and guess what it was, an actual never-before opened copy of Star Wars Knights Of the Old Republic II. I was allowed to play the game afterwards and at first I found it quite confusing, but now it's like a third language to me. But now let's get into why this game is really special. Every weekend, if I was lucky, my best friend and I would have a sleep over at each others house. Every weekend we would play star wars knights of the old republic, we would always take turns, playing with our own and each others characters. but then in 2010 our dog rummaged through my games, and decided to destroy my copy of this game. It's needless to say that I was furious. But the thing is, that only cd3 and 4 broke, the other two were completely damaged. This meant that I could only play this at my friend's house, but we didn't mind. Me and my friend played it untill our very last year together, before I moved.

I rate this game, and the memories that come with it 999999999999/10

Live long Hornik Hayne

reviewText:
When playing through the game, be sure to install the Restored Content Mod and the M4-78EP mod. These will allow you to play the game as closely to how the Obsidian development team originally wanted the game to be played. This is easily my favorite Star Wars game to date, and it is also in my Top 5 favorite games of all-time. At the time of this review, I have only played 1 playthrough on Steam. I completely engulfed myself in the game and did not skip through any cutscenes or dialogue. I did skip through Peragus though (because I find it to be more of a tutorial level than anything) by using the Skip Peragus mod.

Pros:
- The main questline is very elaborate and well thought out. There are also many sidequests to do along the way that will enhance your view of the galaxy.
- The seemingly unimportant dialogue choices you make during the game can have significant effects down the road.
- I felt that this game was much more visually appealing than the original KotOR. It also seemed to me that the game ran smoother as well, although that might just be me.
- The characters that join you along the way have their own pasts and interesting stories.
- Subpoint: Depending if you are Light Side or Dark Side or Male or Female, you get different allies along the way. You can also influence them more depending on which way you side.
- Many unique and interesting force powers learned along the way.
- There is a prestige" system setup for later in the game. In the beginning you can choose what type of Jedi you will be (Guardian
hoursPlayed:
but around level 20 you are given the option to become a better version of one of those.

Cons:
- The game does have its bugs (the TSLRCM should fix most of those problems though).
- Gaining the influence of your allies is often difficult
voteText: or even impossible
helpfulPercent: if you are of a different force side as them (i.e if you are a Jedi
votesHelpful: it'll be harder to gain influence from one of your allies who leans more towards the dark side).\n- I wish there was just a little bit more to the end of the game. *SPOILERS* I felt that after you defeat Darth Traya
votesTotal: you should be able to go back
votesFunny: see how your decisions affected the Republic
commentsCount: and then go off into the Unknown Regions in search of Revan.\n- There are places where I thought were just a bit too thin. Like could they have given us a little bit more?\n- Even though the game supposedly levels up as you do
column16:
you basically are able to just plow through everyone without even trying.

Conclusion: 9/10
May the Force be with You."

reviewText:
KOTOR II has been one of my favorite RPGs since the day I first played it. Many people seem to consider this game a disappointment after KOTOR I, but I played KOTOR I first and still prefer KOTOR II by orders of magnitude.

In KOTOR II, you're playing as the Exile, a (you guessed it) exiled Jedi whose connection to the force was severed when he or she chose to walk away. As you progress, you slowly regain your character's former strength, and the main plot has you hunting down your former Jedi masters to either save or destroy them, depending on how you want to handle the situation.

KOTOR II has excellent writing, first and foremost. Its moral choices are great, much better than those found in KOTOR I (which is a game I love dearly).  It has a better cast of villains that KOTOR I, which is something that can make or break a good story. The cast of party members is great, and your influence over them will affect their appearance, their demeanor, and even their skills. Many of the people who join your crew can be trained into Jedi (or Sith) if your influence over them is high enough, which is a great feature.

A big difference between KOTOR I and KOTOR II is that in KOTOR II, you begin the game as a Jedi. It takes quite some time to be able to get your first lightsaber (although you can fast track the process by making the right choices), but starting out as a Jedi lets you build your character that way from the beginning, instead of KOTOR I's awkward pre-Jedi class system. Furthermore, when you reach a high enough level, you can choose a specialization for your character which grants new and unique abilities depending on your choice.

It's true that this game has a lot of cut content, but we live in the age of The Sith Lords Restored Content mod, which takes an already great game and makes it into an undeniably better game that its predecessor. I cannot recommend that mod enough. Way back when, Obsidian was forced to rush KOTOR II out the door. As a result, a lot of planned content was cut. However, they shipped all that content with the game, hidden away and unusable, in the hopes that modders would take it and restore it. They did. Now that KOTOR II has Steam Workshop integration, installing the Restored Content mod is a breeze for anybody, and I would go so far as to say it's essential if you want the KOTOR II experience as it was meant to be.

KOTOR II is honestly one of the only games I'd go so far to call a masterpiece. If you've ever avoided this game because you heard it's not as good as KOTOR I, I would urge you to give it a try and see how great it is for yourself. INSTALL THE RESTORED CONTENT MOD THOUGH.

However, they shipped all that content with the game, hidden away and unusable, in the hopes that modders would take it and restore it. They did. Now that KOTOR II has Steam Workshop integration, installing the Restored Content mod is a breeze for anybody, and I would go so far as to say it's essential if you want the KOTOR II experience as it was meant to be.

KOTOR II is honestly one of the only games I'd go so far to call a masterpiece. If you've ever avoided this game because you heard it's not as good as KOTOR I, I would urge you to give it a try and see how great it is for yourself. INSTALL THE RESTORED CONTENT MOD THOUGH.

reviewText:
Easily one of the greatest games of all time. 10 years later the characters still haunt me. I still can't think of the Force the same way after playing this game. It's examination of what the Force is and what is means to connect to it, Jedi or Sith. There is a depth to the story that few books, games, movies, comics, or any other media can touch. There are hard choices and a hardness to the story that truly makes it stand out among it's peers. KoToR 1 was A New Hope, bright and hopeful, black and white, just touching on the edges of a deep and murky pool. KoToR 2 is Empire Strikes Back. The true depth of the universe is unveiled and it is a much more serious and grey, melancholy and doubt and revelation intertwined.

The combat is wonderful. Using a d20 based combat system the options are limitless and powerful. By the end of the game you truly feel like a seasoned Sith or Jedi Master, crushing armies with a gesture.

The recent update has made the game even better. Bugfixes and native widescreen support alongside the Steam Workshop. The Sith Lords Restored Content Mod (TSLRCM) in nearly required. It adds tons of content and story that was cut for reasons left unexplained.

Buy it, play it, remember it in 10 years and wonder how you can change the galaxy the next time.

reviewText:
One of the best games I've played. While the combat may be a bit boring (read MMO-esk), the writing of this game is superb. And while it takes time to get past some of the early stuff, it eventually hooks you and it makes you feel like you must see where the plot line will go. Companions are excellently written and while you may not agree with all of them from the beginning, it really feels that you are given ability to guide and teach them through dialogue and your actions. And most of the time it feels like you have options that actually reflect your set of mind for each situation with companions and quests. There are some fetch quest type of tasks that are a bit boring but most of the bigger quest lines are interesting and well written and feel meaningful.

Controller support worked fine, if felt adequate for the game and I didn't miss mouse and keyboard for controlling the game. Workshop support was nice addition, it streamlined the installation of the mods.

If you are willing to set aside moderate amount of time, go through a bit plain beginning and somewhat dull combat, this game has some of the best writing I have ever encountered in gaming.

reviewText:
I played this years ago back on the original xbox and I have to admit I enjoyed this game far more than the first KOTOR. Personally I think the sith lords is heavily underrrated compared to the first game in the series.

The gameplay is pretty much the same as the first games with a couple of tweaks but not much but needless to say it plays well for it's time.

What really got to me was the story, it was downright dark and bleak compared to KOTOR 1's plot and that was something I loved about this. The story spared no punches and even parts of it's themes dissected the star wars universe and mythos allowing us to see it in new ways and ask some questions about it. The story was pretty deep and had some unique characters which is why the expanded universe retcon was such a heavy blow for fans like myself(but we have the clone wars etc we're good LOL111)

But snark aside this is a good game. If you enjoyed the first one then you will most likely enjoy this but I would say it's worth getting the lost content mod because it restores a lot of meat to the game. theres also a couple of other mods worth hunting down to polish things and add a few extras if that floats your boat.

reviewText:
Rating 7.5/10


Note: I played with the restoration mod. It is HIGHLY recommended that you play with this mod as it fixes a lot of bugs/glitches as well as restore lost content. It brings the game closer to the original intentions of the developers

The Good:

+ The game has a lot of robust options in how you build your character. You start by choosing between 3 classes: Guardian, Consular or Sentinel. Each class obviously focuses on different aspects of combat. Further in the game you can then further specialize your classes. You can fully customize your character how you wish between attributes, skills, feats and Jedi powers. All of this leads to many different options and replayability in how you design your character

+ The core aspect of the game is that as you can either play as a Jedi that is good or evil. Saving people, being kind and choosing the peaceful solution leads you to the light side while doing the opposite leads you to the dark side. Doing so leads to certain bonuses to your Jedi Powers. Being good means Light side powers will use less mana and dark side powers cost more and vice versa. I find the system to be very effective because it ties morality choices into game play, a feature that seems to be very lacking in today's modern games.

+ The second core aspect is how you respond and handle situations with your party members. You can gain or lose influence with them. If you gain enough influence with any particular party member, new dialogue options open up resulting in more background to the story, and/or stat increases for you or your party member. It is not mandatory as you can easily complete the game without gaining any influence with anybody but it adds a nice touch to the game and offers more options.

+ The story, although confusing in the beginning because it throws so much at you does get increasingly better. The story is presented very well because of the great dialogue options and fantastic writing. Obsidian is easily one of the best in the industry regarding writing.

+ If there is any company that can match or exceed Bioware in writing for npc characters its Obsidian. Every party member that joins you in your quest is well written and interesting. Every party member has alternative motives for joining you which makes things more exciting and not every party member gets along with each other. These ideas are explored the further you progress in the game.

+ Every planet you visit feels different. The game throws a few twists in for good measure to keep things fresh.

+ Well written Side Quests

+ mods


The Average:

Sadly there was no improvement with combat. The combat in the game is really showing its age. I never particularly liked the combat because it's not very engaging.

Certain force powers, skills, feats are game breaking while others are completely useless.


The Bad:

- The UI especially navigating to find items in your inventory is a chore and frustrating. The inventory screen is a long list of your items. There are options to filter the list based on specific items but this doesn't fix the overall problem of a bad overall inventory management system.

- The game forces you to do solo missions either as yourself or one of your party members. These sections are frustrating and awful only because the combat was never designed around solo play. This problem is further compounded if you auto-leveled up any of your party members. Playing a solo section with a party member that has all the wrong attributes/skills/feats is painful.

- Last few areas have cut and paste environments. Obvious that development was rushed at the end.


Conclusion

A worthy follow up to one of the best RPG's for its time. Obsidian once again shows that it is one of the best when it comes to writing a great story with great characters. It's sad that it takes a mod to fix a lot of the problems with the game. If you loved the first game then there is no reason not to love this one as well.

reviewText:
A flawed classic. There are so many ways to complete quests and different dialogue choices that change the story. The combat can be unbalanced when you get your first lightsaber and you just spam master flurry attack. Once you get a lightsaber, there is no better weapon and you might as well duel-wield them rather than go two-handed as you do more damage overall. You actually don't get your first lightsaber until 7-10 hours into the game. Instead you have to build it by completing optional quests (make sure to look up the Nar Shadaa one, it is very easy to screw up the quest that gives you a part). The lightsaber is teased multiple times throughout the first two planets, but it isn't a let down when you get it. Instead, it opens up new unlockable moves such as using force jump to jump thirty feet and stab a guy and a dialogue tree to become a true Jedi or Sith, which unlocks more moves!
TLDR: If you can get around the crashes and performance issues, you can find an experience akin to Bioware's Mass Effect series (they also made KoTR1) and Fallout New Vegas (which was also made by Obsidian).

Update: Whelp, they updated the game. Now there aren't any bugs, crashes, or performance issues. Now you can also use a controller, which is awesome as I first played this on the original Xbox. The story is still pretty sweet and so is the combat, but it can be quite unforgiving if you don't pay attention and blaze through everything without reading (Hint: you may think force speed is trash, but it allows you to attack two extra times each turn you attack. Master flurry also gives you an extra attack with no downsides, so spend those rare upgrade points wisely!)

reviewText:
This is an interesting take on Star Wars, the Old Republic timeline. KOTOR 1 was astronomically critically successful, so I'll assume familiarity with that. This sequel to that legendary RPG takes things further and is 100% worth your time.

Bioware's KOTOR 1 was about Good vs Evil, and was groundbreaking with its moral decisions and player agency. Obsidian's KOTOR 2 is a deconstruction of the more normal Good vs Evil themes - it goes deeper into questions of what makes right and what makes wrong. It's not just about choosing to be good or choosing to be bad - Obsidian put more effort into making the themes more nuanced than that, and often the player will second-guess their choices and think very carefully about such things as greater goods, or ends justifying means - moreso than in the more straight forward KOTOR 1, anyway.

KOTOR 1 is a great game and one of my all-time favorite RPGs. KOTOR 2 one-ups it in narrative and maintains the same gameplay and structure that made KOTOR 1 great.

Be sure to get the Sith Lords Restored mod that is on the Steam Workshop. KOTOR 2 was originally released in quite a rushed state (as Obsidian games unfortunately often are) but that mod restores" much of the missing content and really improves the base game.

"

reviewText:
It's been awhile since I finished the first one but this game felt like more of the same both good and bad.

It's funny that this ui would be acceptable not so long ago, maybe it would have been better with a controller, but cycling through all the powers was grating on me towards the end.

I did play on pc with both The Sith Lords Restored Content Mod and M4-78, no bugs, maybe still more difficult to get it to run than it should be but not the same kinds of difficult problems I had with KotOR.

I liked the story, but the characters were not as good as the first game. going back to some of the areas from KotOR was a highlight, I wish they had more cameos or returning characters from the first.

Jedi are really overpowered, to the point I couldn't get much done without one in my party. The game was appropriately difficult, there were some spots I died, but I didn't have any screaming ♥♥♥♥ moments like some of the bosses from the first game.

Good villains, good adventure, a great companion to those that enjoyed the first game.

reviewText:
Truly an underrated masterpiece. One of the most engaging stories of any RPG I've ever played and manages to stay fresh even after so many years. Dialogue and character development were impeccable, especially Kreia, being one of the deepest and profound characters I've encountered in any video game. The amount of ways you can play through the campaign is boggling, I've run through this game about 4 times and still I feel like there were things that I missed.

The Restored Content Mod is vital to anyone who's played this game before. It gives a more satisfying ending as well as some extra cutscenes.

Wouldn't recomment the M4-78 Mod though. Though enticing as the prospect of an extra planet is, the maps were horribly designed and badly paced. It physically pained me to play M4-78.

PLAY. THIS. GAME.

reviewText: If you're a fan of Star Wars, good storytelling and slightly turn-based RPGs, then I'd highly recommend this series. Fortunately, you can play this one without having played the first one, because alot of the previous game's events are discussed at length. This game also features one of my favorite Star Wars universe characters OF ALL TIME, which is Kreia. She is a very mysterious character who you meet at the beginning of the game. Throughout the story, she is an extremely important figure who lives the grey area between Jedi and Sith and who serves as a mentor to your character. Pay ALOT of attention to everything she does and you'll see what I mean when I say she's one of the most interesting people in Star Wars lore. As for everything else, the turn-based combat is solidly constructed, the characters and dialogue are pretty well-written and the graphics aren't half bad for an old Xbox game. Be prepared to play through a few times to get all the dialogue trees for each character unlocked. Not one of them is a waste of time, as each can strengthen your allies and your own character as well. You can also train the majority of your party to become Force users, which is cool.

reviewText:
A rpg every star wars fan shoud play.

They built this planet themselves and I have to give them props for that. The mission isn't designed well and becomes quite confusing and frustrating and with it being a mod there isn't alot of clear walkthroughs.
After going through M4-78EP once I wouldn't want to again. Just a heads up for someone who would play it with the mod.

reviewText:
As a massive Star Wars fan and RPG fan, and a huuuuuuuge KOTOR fan, I believe KOTOR 2 TSL lives up to the first game.

Rating: 9/10

Pros:

- A good, classic RPG.
- In depth story & lore. There's a lot of detail that I feel was ahead of its time.
- Just plain overall fun. It's easy to learn, easy to play, but hard to beat.
- PUZZLES! I enjoy me some puzzles, and this game has them of all sorts of difficulties.

Cons:

- The game was rushed, so there's some bugs & missing content. THANKFULLY there's a mod that finished the missing content and fixed the bugs, and it's available here on the Workshop!
- It can get *really* hard at points. I don't mind, I like a good challenge, but if you're an RPG breezer style player you're going to hit some rough spots in the game.

reviewText:
KOTOR 2 is hands down one of my top favorite games. I was a huge fan of the first one and fell in love with the second one. You can play this game without playing the first one, but you will miss some references and details. The gameplay is the same (fast turn-based) and is a true RPG but it doesn't bog you down with too much. The pause feature is also very helpful to plan combat, especially under a hard difficulty. The graphics are unfortunately a bit dated, so they have that early 2000s look. The music is wonderful and one of my favorite gaming soundtracks.

The characters in KOTOR 2 are unique and you can access their backstories through character influence. There is still a Karma Meter but the main theme of KOTOR 2 is questioning the light/dark or Jedi/Sith dichonomy. The story does have holes due to the unfornuate rush to finish the game. This can best be seen in the ending, However, I would highly recommend the Restored Content Mod, which fixes some plot holes, adds deleted lines and characters, adds cut ending details, and fixes TONS of bugs: http://www.moddb.com/mods/the-sith-lords-restored-content-mod-tslrcm

Despite the existing holes, the game is great. If you liked the first game, like Star Wars, or even just like RPGS, I would highly recommend giving the game a try!

reviewText: (ATTENTION: CONTAINS SPOILERS) KOTOR 2 is a great game. It fully captures the feeling from KOTOR and expands on many key features, such as force powers and weapon/armor upgrades. It added many new feats/powers which make your character more specialized or well rounded. You really begin to feel like you are actually interacting with the NPC's on planets and within your own party, due to new dialogue options and the new influence system. Even though it can be buggy and has its fair share of glitchs, it is still easy to pick up and is an amazing sequel. (SPOILERS START HERE->) I was really pleased with how you are able to convert certain members of your party into Jedi of various classes, and how you can acquire different companions based of your gender and elignment. I also enjoyed how HK-47 was in the game. The only issue i had was  at the end, when you meet with the Jedi masters on Dantooine. I felt like i never actually won out when playing light sided characters. I was always branded as a sith, or an enemy, despite my alignment and this really displeases me. I would have liked to be acknowledged for my ability to hear the force once again and rejoin the fight against the Sith, but it seemed that no matter what i did, i kept being branded a traitor and a dark sider. But other than that, the game was top notch, and i recommend it to everyone, especially fans of KOTOR and SWTOR.

reviewText:
Well as a more distant sequel to the first game, they give you KOTOR II.

KOTOR II has a lot more depth when it comes to gameplay overall and different battle interactions.
But at the same time is riddled with something im going to talk about.

The story aspect has been driven away from the traditional KOTOR/RPG style, instead of a two sided light/vs/dark there is a far more greyzoned area, which will make you think again of who is really right and wrong in your aspect.
There are several nods to the previous game (no spoilers) such as Carth, Bastila, your characters future fate, depending on what path you chose and descision made throughout the game.
This makes the story part a WHOLE lot intresting as it creates a dilemma where right is hard to tell from wrong.

Now enough about this, the biggest downsides to this sequel was the production period. The game was rushed, and a lot of content cut, no debate, and as a result there is a huge amount of content missing, and a lot of, and when I say a lot of I MEAN A LOT OF BUGS, some which may even be game breaking, to a point where you are forced to restart or go a load way back to a earlier save. (trust me I had to play through this twice to even get half through the game)

Now this can be fixed by installing the TLSCRM mod which, through amazing modders enabled players to play cut content with a lot less bugs, as well as fixed and missing dialogue and bug fixes in the game itself, honestly I can´t even think of how I would´ve gotten through the game without this mod.

Anyway conlusively this game is definitly worth it for the story, the combat is meh, and is sadly bug ravaged, execpt with the TLSCRM mod, which is practially essential.

reviewText:
This game is usually overlooked because of Kotor 1, but i think it deserves more credit. While Kotor 1 is my favorite of the two, Kotor 2 is still a great game, with an original story and some of the most brilliant writing i have seen in a video game.

The reason that i think this game does not get as much credit as the first one, is because it has a much more darker story compared to the first one. While Kotor has the traditional Star Wars story, where it is Good Vs. Evil (which is delivered in an amazing way through it's characters), Kotor 2 instead has a much more philosophical perspective on the Force. They make you question both the Jedi and the Sith, and shows that the Force is more complex, instead of it being just black and white. However, most people seem to prefer the traditonal story instead, which is why this does not get as much attention.

Of course, this game has one big flaw. It was rushed and was therefore released in a rather unfinished state. But this can be resolved by getting the Restored Content Mod, which restores a lot of the content that was cut from the game. And just like the First one, you can also download a lot of mods to the game, that makes it even more awesome.

This was kind of a crappy review, but i just wanted to shortly explain why this is a great game, and why you should get it.
If you do get it, it is a must to download the Restored Content Mod, because it makes the game more enjoyable.

My Verdict: 8.5/10 (vanilla version)
9/10 (With Restored Content Mod)
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Update: The update has made it that much better, it was such a enjoyable experience with the acheivments.

Kotor 2 is one of the best rpg's of all time, and one of the best star war's games, if not the very best.

Pro's:
The story is truely amazing,
The gameplay is fun with ways to edit it to make it more enjoyable (Such as makeing it pause after evrey attack, or kep going)
Character Leveling is very well done (Makes you fill like your playing a table top game)
Side missions are very intresting, many of them are very very fun, and add great addition to the game.
The soundtrack goes along with the game very well.
Good/ Evil system, makes you really think about your actions, and what the consequnces will be.
Hk-47 Is really Kick ***, and has some of the best lines in gaming history.

What really sets this game apart from the first one (Which is also good, but no where as good as kotor 2)
Is your companions.
Dont like one of them? Disagree with evreything and lose influence
Like one of them? They will be influenced more
Dont want to collect parts for one? Sucks for you, you miss out on a amazing character concept.
Say the right thing's to a person? You can learn more about their past
Wish someone was a jedi? With enough influence and talking, you can get most characters down this path.
Your playing a good character? Your allies will go down this path as well, giveing better responses.
Going down the bad path? Your allies will go down also, Their character portrits will change also (baodur looks awesome down the bad path btw)
What is your characters gender? One allie depends on this.

The cons:
Can be glitchy at times
(even though i alredy said glitchy) The jedi temple with atris is completly broken
Some of the worlds can get boreing after multiple play throughs (But this happens on any game)
The fact that its a perfect game, and it makes it difficult to think of cons.

This is overall a perfect game
11/10 Defently worth playing

reviewText:
I literally could not be happier with this development, and especially now that the game is rightly regarded as a brilliant classic. See, I got it on release and remember the sheer, unfiltered hate that this game recieved.  This was pretty much all because it wasn't KOTOR 1 - a by-the-numbers RPG with a hot jedi lady and redeemed by a masterful plot twist.   Reading the hate was like visiting the COD forum, bland idiocy about how Atton wasn't Carth (Thank God for that, he's one of the most boring characters ever) - or how there wasn't an easy surrogate for Bastilla in this game (OMFG NO WAIFU?!?! what am I gonna dooooooO!)

In fact this pretty mucy sums up Kotor2 in a nutshell.  It has a far darker, more complex story than the first with fewer cliches and cop outs - and of course Kreia, one of the best characters ever in a game.

Although the cut content in the original did give the second half of the game a very appropriate feeling of desolate emptiness, the restoration patch greatly improves the overall quality of the game and, though the barren finale somehow made sense to me in vanilla (how appropriate, given what we know about the exile?), it's far superior with the restored content.

Maybe finally people will wake up and realize that this game is better than the original.

reviewText:
Even with all its flaws, this game (with its restored content) is amazing. I enjoyed it much more than I did its prequel.

The primary reason for this is Kreia, who is by far my favorite [spoiler alert] villain in the Star Wars canon. She is definitely one of the most evil. Her obsession with the Exile resolves into being a hatred of the Force. To her, it forcefully imposes direction on an aimless and pointless reality. Even more glaring is when the Force leaves one who is accustomed to its presence. Having seen existence through the underlying fabric that connects all life, only to be betrayed by it: one is deserted and worse than blind. The Exile is a hole in the Force, beautiful to her. But more than this, the Exile herself abandoned the Force.

Kreia's ultimate plan is to achieve by the means of the Exile what was accomplished at Malachor V at the close of the Mandalorian Wars, but on a larger scale: to create a ripple in the Force that would never cease, deafening all of life to the Force's presence by further opening the wound in it. In the end, it seemed to me that Kreia was not much of the Sith that she worked under the pretense of being.

There are more worthwhile elements to the game, but Kreia was by far my favorite. As far as characters go, though, HK-47 was a close second. It is worth getting him as early as possible just to work your way through all of his dialogue. A few of them come to mind.

reviewText: A worthy sequel to the first game, if anything I would've liked to see more variation and a bigger step forward, but this was a very rushed sequel. If you're looking for more KOTOR, then you must play this(get the restored content mod, otherwise I hear this game is pretty awful, this and a few other force power mods made my playthrough really fun). If you weren't a fan of the original, then you definitely won't be liking this one. Story is worse and some of the characters aren't very interesting. A few cast members from the first game show up, and the few new characters seem pretty much like new versions of old ones. Still, I'd definitely recommend it for any RPG fan, and a must play for a huge KOTOR fan like myself.

reviewText:
[UPDATE: THIS GAME NOW HAS ACHIEVEMENTS AND FULL CONTROLLER SUPPORT.]
Ten years after it's initial release in 2005 this game released an update that supports achievements and higher resolutions. I know this is a timeless classic but for a developer to care about this game after so long is astonishing to me, and should be congratulated and praised for the effort put into bringing these amazing games to a new generation.

A long time ago, LucasArts actually made quality titles like Battlefront and Republic Commando. Leading the troop was the Knights of the Old Republic franchise. Now before you play this game, I strongly recommend purchasing the first KotOR game.

Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic II is an amazing game. You don't have to be a fan of Star Wars to enjoy this title. It has everything you would expect from an RPG, and also everything you would expect from a Star Wars game. Unlike other games under the Star Wars name that have you blasting and swinging your lightsaber around an area of helpless battle droids and such, KotOR II is somewhat unique in a sense of accomplishment. There are many times where instead of activating your lightsaber and cutting everyone down, you'll have to find your way out of sticky situations with reason or wit. The key to being a good KotOR player is judging when to engage a firefight or when to think things through. Do you attack that Rancor head-on or do you sneak over and poison it's food?

This doesn't mean you'll never see combat. In Knights of the Old Republic II you start off choosing what JEDI class you want to be, (which includes Sentinel, Consular, or Guardian) rather than picking if you want to be a Soldier, Scout, or Scoundrel. This means that right from the get-go of the game you'll have the ability to start stacking up on Force Powers you're going to need in the future. Depending on what you pick, your play style will change.

Guardians focus on swordfighting and combat rather than force powers and skills.

Sentinels mediate between the two, balancing out between swordplay and sorcery.

Consulars are extremely powerful in the force.

Just like the original KotOR, you will start picking skills and feats that allow you to perform various actions. If you put a lot of skill points into Persuasion, you can talk your way out of scenarios before it breaks out into a battlefield. Spend a lot of points on Computer Use or Repair, you can slice into control consoles or reactivate droids to get leverage on your enemies. Then there are skills like Treat Injury and such that allow you to heal wounds faster and give you more HP.

KotOR 2 brings a new feature to the franchise, and allows you to use components and chemicals to create / breakdown items. You can break down a Vibrosword and turn it into components, and then use the broken down components to build a Frag Grenade or Mine.

In summary, KotOR II is not only a great Star Wars game but one of the best RPG's ever created. The story and cast will keep you interested, and the gorgeous worlds from the jungle moon of Dxun to the Czerka Starport of Telos offer tons of chances to explore.

(Plus, be sure to download the Restored Content mod if you plan on purchasing this game, as it adds in TONS of content that was deleted by Obisidan due to time contraints.)
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
*DISCLAIMER: LIke my kotor 1 review i did not play this as a child, infact i just recently bought it but have been unable to beat it.*

Many think as this game to be the little brother of KOTOR 1 who looks up and tries to be just like his brother. Well KOTOR 2 is like 1 a little too much for my taste. While this is a good game and i absolutley recommend this game take the following into concideration.

1: It looks just like KOTOR 1 graphically wise almost as if they were unable to make any improvment, this isn't much of a problem but its just that KOTOR 1 was in 2003, this in 2005 you are really going to sit there and tell me you didn't have the ablilty to make it look any better than the one made 2 years ago? i know technology doesn't develop fast but the least they could do was give the character rounder noses so you didn't feel like you needed to wear saftey glasses while playing.

2: Exact same battle system and control scheme.

3: The story line does not feel very energetic to me, you are a ex-jedi running from the sith till you can build up enough strength to be able to storm in the capital ship singing take on me" while slaughtering anything that even looks barely sentient.

Other than that i really enjoy this game and highly recommend it to anyone getting into the star wars franchise 9/10"
